revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Abel Cain | image = | alt = | caption = | director = [[Alejandro Jodorowsky]] | producer = [[David Lynch]] (rumoured)
[[Parallel Media]] (estimated) | writer = Alejandro Jodorowsky | starring = [[Axel Jodorowsky]] | music = [[Adan Jodorowsky]] | cinematography = [[Vilmos Zsigmond]] | editing = | distributor = | released = Not yet released | runtime = | country = United States
Spain
Russia | language = [[Spanish language|Spanish]]
English }} '''''Abel Cain''''' (formerly known as '''''Sons of El Topo''''') is a stalled film project written and directed by [[Alejandro Jodorowsky]] and the sequel to Jodorowsky's classic [[acid Western]] film ''[[El Topo]]''. It was to be produced and financed by Parallel Media.{{cite news|author=Steve Rose |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/nov/14/alejandro-jodorowosky-el-topo |title=Lennon, Manson and me: the psychedelic cinema of Alejandro Jodorowsky | Film |publisher=The Guardian |date= 2009-11-14|accessdate=2011-01-07 |location=London}} In a 2010 interview, Jodorowsky said that the film had "dragged a long time" and suggested that Abel Cain will not feature any "stars", adding that he would cast his son Axel Jodorowsky in the lead role just as he did in his 1989 [[cult classic]] film ''[[Santa Sangre]]''.{{cite web|url=http://translate.google.fi/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=fi&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.excessif.com%2Fcinema%2Factu-cinema%2Fdossiers%2Fcarte-blanche-alejandro-jodorowsky-6061921-760.html |title=Google Kääntäjä |language=fi |publisher=Translate.google.fi |date= |accessdate=2011-01-07}} It was expected to be released sometime between late 2011 to 2012, but appears to be shelved so that he may shoot his biopic, ''[[The Dance of Reality]]'' first.{{cite news| url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2011/01/26/alejandro-jodorowsky-a-spirited-talk-with-the-santa-sangre-director/ | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=Todd | last=Gilchrist | title=Alejandro Jodorowsky: A Spirited Talk With The 'Santa Sangre' Director | date=2011-01-26}} In a November 29 interview, Jodorowsky announced that he had found financing for the film and would begin shooting the project in September in Mexico after he is finished with ''[[The Dance of Reality]]''. During an interview at the [[Cannes Film Festival]] in 2016, Jodorowsky announced his plans to finally make ''The Son of El Topo'' as soon as financial backing is obtained.Skinner, Craig (2016). [http://www.flickreel.com/the-son-of-el-topo-or-a-sensual-travel-to-be-alejandro-jodorowskys-next-film-after-endless-poetry/ ''THE SON OF EL TOPO OR A SENSUAL TRAVEL TO BE ALEJANDRO JODOROWSKY’S NEXT FILM AFTER ENDLESS POETRY (CANNES FILM FESTIVAL BREAKING NEWS)''], Flickreel.com, 15 May 2016 Also in 2016 the sequel to ''El Topo'' was released in comic book form as ''Sons of El Topo'' (the original title for the project), in a miniseries written by Jodorowsky and illustrated by [[José Ladrönn]].{{cite web|url=http://www.glenatbd.com/bd/les-fils-d-el-topo-tome-1-9782344004487.htm |title=Les Fils d'El Topo - Tome 1 - Caïn par Alejandro Jodorowsky |publisher=Glenatbd.com |date=2016-06-08 |accessdate=2016-12-09}} == Synopsis == After a [[nuclear apocalypse]], the whole landscape is a desert ruin, except for a small island paradise where El Topo is buried. Though visible and seemingly accessible, every attempt to enter this island has resulted in disaster. El Topo's sons, Cain and Abel, were separated as boys because El Topo predicted that Cain would kill Abel. But when evil marauders steal their mothers's body in an attempt to trick their way into the island, the brothers join forces to deliver their dead mother to be buried with their father. Not only must they overcome an enemy adept at technological witchery, they must overcome the curse that marks their destiny.{{cite web|url=https://pro.imdb.com/title/tt0187679/ |title=IMDb Pro : Abel Cain Business Details |publisher=Pro.imdb.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-07}}http://www.parallelmediafilms.com/#/films/abelcain ==Production== Alejandro Jodorowsky began attempting to resurrect his film career in the mid-nineties after becoming disillusioned with the business during his poor experience on ''The Rainbow Thief'' and attempted to market a sequel to his classic ''[[El Topo (1970 film)|El Topo]]'', and created a teaser poster.{{cite web|url=http://www.hotweird.com/jodorowsky/sons.html |title=The Sons Of El Topo |publisher=Hotweird.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521175025/http://www.hotweird.com/jodorowsky/sons.html |archivedate=2011-05-21 }} Originally ''Sons of El Topo'' was to star [[Marilyn Manson]] and [[Johnny Depp]], but the funding never materialized and Jodorowsky shortly abandoned the project.{{cite web|url=http://www.short-biographies.com/biographies/AlejandroJodorowsky.html |title=Biography of Alejandro Jodorowsky |publisher=Short-biographies.com |date=1929-02-07 |accessdate=2011-01-07}} Jodorowsky next attempted to make a "metaphysical gangster film" entitled ''[[King Shot]]'', which was to be produced by David Lynch and star Marilyn Manson and Nick Nolte. He drew numerous conceptual sketches{{cite web|url=http://123nonstop.com/pictures/King_Shot |title=Pictures King Shot |publisher=123nonstop.com |date=2010-07-13 |accessdate=2011-01-07}}{{cite web|url=http://technoccult.net/archives/category/alejandro-jodorowsky/ |title=Alejandro Jodorowsky |publisher=Technoccult.net |date= |accessdate=2011-01-07}} and heavily marketed the film to producers, but eventually he and Lynch abandoned the project after they were only able to acquire a portion of the budget necessary to shoot the film and Jodorowsky was given another opportunity to make his "dream project". In a November 2009 interview with ''The Guardian'', Jodorowsky revealed that he had stopped trying to make ''King Shot'', but had finally been given financing for the sequel to ''El Topo'' by some "Russian producers" who own Parallel Media films. == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [https://oneroomwithaview.com/2014/08/22/best-films-never-made-19-alejandro-jodorowskys-abel-cain-king-shot/ Best Films Never Made #19: Alejandro Jodorowsky's ''Abel Cain'' and ''King Shot'' - By Conor Morgan. August 22, 2014] One Room With A View {{Alejandro Jodorowsky}} {{Cain and Abel}} [[Category:2010s unfinished films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Russian films]] [[Category:Spanish films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Spanish-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Alejandro Jodorowsky]] [[Category:Sequel films]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox video game |collapsible = |state = |title = Alien Breed 3: Descent | image = Alien Breed 3 - Descent Coverart.png |caption = |developer = [[Team17]] |publisher = Team17 |series = ''[[Alien Breed]]'' |engine = [[Unreal Engine 3]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 3]] ([[PlayStation Network]]), [[Xbox 360]] ([[Xbox Live Arcade]]) |released = November 17, 2010 |genre = [[Isometric shooter]]
[[Survival horror]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }} '''''Alien Breed 3: Descent''''' is the sequel of ''[[Alien Breed 2: Assault]]'' and is the third and final installment of the episodic [[Video game remake|remake]] of the ''[[Alien Breed]]'' series.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-360/alien-breed-3-descent|title=Metacritic Alien Breed 3: Descent|publisher=Metacritic|accessdate=8 May 2011}} == Plot == Conrad fight with Klien AI inside MIAs body, after beating Klien, MIA is disembodied but regains her conscience, she then tell Conrad the only way he can destroy Klien maniacal AI by used her brain core as EMP device to fry him. After several hours of falling to Frozen with Ice planet and then drown into it waters, Conrad encounter the Alien Queen which was created by Klien and that he is overjoyed with his creation, Klien says it took him about a hundred years to create a controllable Queen, Klien tells Conrad that he copied him self to Leopold spaceship and about to leave with out Conrad, after a battle with Queen Conrad continue his crusade into Klien mainframe lair, where he battle him and his still alive Alien Queen, in the heat of battle Alien Queen falls at Klien AI mainframe and destroy important tech in order for Klien to operate therefor opening a small control room, Conrad uses EMP which MIA gave him and fry Klien for good...in the aftermath we see Conrad finally attending his should wound and taking a nap, a small pad falls on the ground, pad starts to show the image logo of Klien Eye and we can hear Klien talking...but can't hear what he is saying. == Gameplay == ''Alien Breed 3: Descent'', like ''[[Alien Breed Evolution|Evolution]]'' and ''Assault'', is a [[shooter game|shooter]] set on board a futuristic [[spacecraft]]. In each level, the main character Conrad is given a series of tasks such as collecting key cards, restoring power to various systems, and clearing rooms of hazardous substances (e.g. halon gas or excess water). All tasks must be completed before finding that level's exit in the form of an elevator. Standing in his way are a variety of aliens who will attack him, usually en masse. He can also suffer damage from explosions, fires, electrical disturbances, and enemy turrets. Conrad can run and shoot in all directions, and can collect a number of different weapons and items to aid him. He can also purchase additional ammunition, items, and upgrades from shops found at computer terminals which also function as save points. The camera angle can be rotated manually in 45 degree increments. Data pads are spread throughout the game, which when collected, reveal information on the various alien species encountered throughout the game and provide back stories for the game's characters. The game features a "survival" mode in which players might survive for as long as they can against waves of aliens while using whatever weapons and items they can find around the area. This mode is available in single-player and co-op modes. == Reception == {{Video game reviews | MC = PC: 64/100{{Cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/alien-breed-3-descent |title=Alien Breed 3: Descent for PC Review |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=December 3, 2017}}
PS3: 64/100{{Cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-3/alien-breed-3-descent |title=Alien Breed 3: Descent for PlayStation 3 Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=December 3, 2017}}
X360: 68/100{{Cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-360/alien-breed-3-descent |title=Alien Breed 3: Descent for Xbox 360 Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=December 3, 2017}} | EuroG = 7/10{{Cite web |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2010-11-18-download-games-roundup-review?page=3 |title=Download Games Roundup Review |publisher=[[Eurogamer]] |accessdate=December 3, 2017}} | IGN = 6.5/10{{Cite web |url=http://ca.ign.com/games/alien-breed-3-descent/pc-89577 |title=Alien Breed 3: Descent - PC |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=December 3, 2017}} | GameZone = 5.5/10{{Cite web |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101203135953/http://pc.gamezone.com/reviews/item/alien_breed_3_descent_review/ |title=Alien Breed 3: Descent |publisher=GameZone |accessdate=December 3, 2017}} }} ''Alien Breed 3: Descent'' received mixed reviews from critics. On [[Metacritic]], the game holds scores of 64/100 for the PC version based on 15 reviews, 64/100 for the PlayStation 3 version based on 7 reviews, and 68/100 for the Xbox 360 version based on 16 reviews == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.team17.com/games/alien-breed/alien-breed-3-descent}} * {{MobyGames|id=/alien-breed-3-descent|name=''Alien Breed 3: Descent''}} {{portal bar|Video games|2010s}} {{Team17}} [[Category:2010 video games]] [[Category:Episodic video games]] [[Category:Horror video games]] [[Category:PlayStation Network games]] [[Category:Science fiction video games]] [[Category:Team17]] [[Category:Unreal Engine games]] [[Category:Video game sequels]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 Live Arcade games]] {{shooter-videogame-stub}}

[[Saint Andrew's Junior College]]
[[Nanyang Technological University]] | nationality = [[Singaporean]] | occupation = {{flatlist| * Actress * Singer-songwriter * scriptwriter * [[creative director|director]] * [[YouTube personality]] }} | years_active = 2015–present | agent = | genre = [[Electrofolk]], Pop | instrument = Piano, guitar, harmonica | label = | agentcompany = | yearsactive = | associatedact = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | siblings = | relatives = | ancestry = [[Peranakan]]
[[Hokkien]] | influences = {{unbulleted list|[[Brooke Fraser]]|[[Coldplay]]|[[For King & Country (band)|For King And Country]]}} | influenced = | website = {{Facebook|annetterochellelee|Annette Lee}} | alias = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | currentmembers = | pastmembers = | hongkongfilmwards = | goldenbauhiniaawards = | hkfcsawards = | asianfilmawards = | goldenhorseawards = | huabiaoawards = | goldenroosterawards = | hundredflowersawards = | goldeneagleawards = | flyingapsarasawards = | rthktop10goldsongsawards= | goldenmelodyawards = | mtvasiaawards = | ntsawards = | chinamusicawards = | goldenbellawards = | tvbanniversaryawards = | magnoliaawards = | asiantvawards = | rainbowawards = | awards = }} '''Annette Rochelle Lee''' (born 10 July 1992), is a [[Singaporeans|Singaporean]] actress, singer-songwriter, scriptwriter, [[creative director|director]] and [[YouTube personality]]. She is best known for her appearances in the popular Singapore media platform [[SGAG]]'s comedic videos under the personas "Sue Ann" and "Suezanna Chole Tan".{{cite website|url=https://www.timeout.com/singapore/music/interview-annette-lee|title=Interview: Annette Lee|publisher=TimeOut|accessdate=2 June 2018|date=14 September 2017}} She released her debut electro-folk [[Extended play|EP]] in 2017. == Early life == Born in Singapore in 10 July 1992 to the parents of [[Peranakan]] descent, Lee studied at [[Saint Andrew's Junior College]], she was graduated from the [[Nanyang Technological University]]’s School of Art Design and Media.{{cite web|url=https://lifestyle.toggle.sg/en/lifestyle/worklife/news/the-secret-life-of-an-sgag-writer-annette-lee-9263112|title=The secret life of an SGAG writer: Annette Lee – Toggle|publisher=}} == Career == Prior to joining [[SGAG]], her short films ''Keep Mum'' and ''Graduation'' were featured in the [[Singapore Short Film Awards]], Cana Film Festival, Hong Kong International Mobile Film Awards.{{Cite web|url=https://www.scape.sg/online/unleash-creative-juices-at-all-in-young-writers-festival|title=Singapore Young Writer's Festival by Scape|website=www.scape.sg|access-date=31 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sindie.sg/2015/06/review-ntu-adm-film-2015-graduation_27.html|title=Review – NTU ADM Film 2015 Graduation Shorts|website=www.sindie.sg}} Lee was first brought to the attention of the SGAG founders from her blog,{{cite web|url=https://contentsummit.asia/speaker/annette-lee/|title=Annette Lee Bio – Content Summit Asia 2017|website=contentsummit.asia|access-date=12 May 2018}} in which she drew comics and shared stories about her life.{{cite magazine |last= |first= |date=1 December 2017 |title= 5 Minutes with Annette Lee |url=https://www.pressreader.com/singapore/cleo-singapore/20171201/281573765977487 |magazine= [[Cleo (magazine)|Cleo]] |location=Singapore |publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings]]|access-date= 12 May 2018}} She joined SGAG in Jan 2016 to start the video team.{{cite web|url=https://vulcanpost.com/624719/content-summit-2017-recap-part-1/|title=Vulcan Post 2017 Content Summit|date=31 October 2017|publisher=Vulcan Post}}{{cite web|url=https://sg.wantedly.com/journals/219|title=How I hire: SGAG's co-founder Karl Mak|website=wantedly.com|date=28 August 2017|access-date=12 May 2018}} She still does writing, directing and acting in many of SGAG's videos. == Music == In September 2017, Lee released her first musical work, an [[Extended play|EP]] titled ''All Our Achilles Heels.'' Her album was awarded the [[National Arts Council, Singapore|National Arts Council]] presentation grant.{{Cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/entertainment/funny-girl-also-sings|title=SGAG funny girl Annette Lee also sings|last=hermes|date=29 October 2017|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2018-05-23|language=en}} In August 2017, Lee released her first music video on Youtube, titled ''Ready for a Savior''.{{cite web|url=http://www.newreleasetoday.com/article.php?article_id=2221|title=#876 – "Ready for a Savior" by ANNETTE|website=www.newreleasetoday.com|date=28 November 2017|access-date=12 May 2018}} Her second music video release in March 2018 was titled ''None Good''.{{cite web|url=http://www.newreleasetoday.com/news_detail.php?newsid=3118|title=ANNETTE Unveils Music Video for 'None Good'|website=www.newreleasetoday.com|date=31 March 2018|access-date=12 May 2018}} ==Filmography== ;Films {| class="wikitable" !Date of release !Title !Role !Note |- |2015 |''Graduation'' |Director, writer, editor |Short film |- |2015 |''Keep Mum'' |Director, writer, editor |Short film |} ;Music Videos {| class="wikitable" !Date of release !Title |- |31 August 2017 |''Ready for a Savior'' |- |30 March 2018 |''None Good'' |} ==Discography== ;EP {| class="wikitable" !Date of release !Title |- |20 September 2017 |''All Our Achilles Heels'' |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/user/annetteandafish Annette's YouTube Channel] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lee, Annette Rochelle}} [[Category:1992 births]] [[Category:Living people]] page.title: Australia in the Eurovision Song Contest

revision.text:
{{Infobox song contest country |Name = Australia |Flag = Flag of Australia.svg |Member station = [[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]] |National selection event = {{Collapsible list | title ='''National final''' | '''Eurovision - Australia Decides''' | 2019 }} {{Collapsible list | title = '''Internal Selection''' | 2015–2018 }} |ESC apps = 4 (4 finals) |ESC first = [[Eurovision Song Contest 2015|2015]] |ESC last = |ESC best = 2nd: [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016|2016]] |ESC worst = 20th: [[Eurovision Song Contest 2018|2018]] |Website = [http://www.sbs.com.au/eurovision/ SBS page] |EBU page = https://eurovision.tv/country/australia |Current = 2019 }}
'''Australia''' has participated in the '''[[Eurovision Song Contest]]''' four times since their debut at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2015|2015 contest]] in [[Vienna]]. The country's best result in the contest is a second-place finish for [[Dami Im]] in {{escyr|2016}}. Australia also finished in the top ten in two of its other appearances in the contest, with [[Guy Sebastian]] finishing fifth in 2015, and [[Isaiah Firebrace]] finishing ninth in {{escyr|2017}}.
Australia's participation in the 2015 contest was set to be a one-off event, the plan being only to perform again the following year had they won, but it was confirmed in November 2015 by [[Sveriges Television|SVT]] that they would participate in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016|2016 contest]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Australien är klar för Eurovision Song Contest 2016 i Stockholm|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/australien-ar-klar-for-eurovision-song-contest-2016-i-stockholm|publisher=Sveriges Television|accessdate=17 November 2015}}</ref> Australia is the first country from the [[Oceania]] region (and the second country outside Eurasia, after [[Morocco in the Eurovision Song Contest|Morocco]] in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1980|1980]]) to participate in the contest.
==History==
===1983–2014=== Australian broadcaster [[Special Broadcasting Service]] (SBS) first broadcast the Eurovision Song Contest in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1983|1983]] and has continued to do so every year since. The contest has attracted a strong viewing audience in Australia, primarily because a significant proportion of the population have ancestry in Europe (in particular in the [[Australia–United_Kingdom_relations|United Kingdom]]). Early broadcasts of the Contest in Australia either featured no commentary or used the {{Esccnty|United Kingdom}}'s commentary as transmitted by the [[BBC]]. In {{ESCYr|2001}}, actress and comedian [[Mary Coustas]] provided commentary for the Contest performing as her comedic character [[Effie Stephanidis|Effie]].<ref name="escinsight.com"/> In {{ESCYr|2002}} and {{ESCYr|2003}}, SBS presenter Des Mangan provided commentary for the Australian audience. From {{ESCYr|2009}}, [[Julia Zemiro]] and [[Sam Pang]] were assigned as commentators for the competition by SBS.<ref>{{cite news |last=Nicholson |first=Sarah |title=Top of the Euro pops |work=Courier Mail |publisher=news.com.au |date=2008-05-21 |url=http://www.news.com.au/couriermail/story/0,23739,23729009-5003422,00.html |accessdate=2008-05-26}}</ref><ref name="Australia 2">{{cite web |url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2009/04/airdate-eurovision-2009.html |title=Airdate: Eurovision 2009 |last=Knox |first=David |date=2009-04-16 |publisher=''TV Tonight'' |accessdate=2009-04-16}}</ref> {{ESCYr|2017}} saw SBS replace the commentators with comedian [[Joel Creasey]] and TV and radio personality [[Myf Warhurst]]. In addition to broadcasting the contest, SBS has also broadcast the [[Congratulations: 50 Years of the Eurovision Song Contest|50th]] and [[Eurovision Song Contest's Greatest Hits|60th]] anniversary programmes.
From 2010 to 2014, SBS allowed Australian viewers to participate in their own televote for the Grand Finals.<ref name="eurovision.tv">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=australian_televoters_choose_their_winner|title=Australian televoters choose their winner|work=Eurovision.tv|accessdate=11 February 2015}}</ref> However, these votes were not counted at the actual contest and did not affect the overall result. The SBS commentary team and Australian delegation were awarded a commentary booth of their own at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2012|2012 contest]] in [[Baku]]. They have been allocated a commentary booth every year since.
In the event that Australia should win the Eurovision Song Contest, the EBU had confirmed that in accordance with the rules, Australia would not host the event in the southern hemisphere, and instead would co-host the contest in Europe.<ref name="Oz-Win">{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=What happens if Australia wins the Eurovision Song Contest?|url=https://eurovoix.com/2017/05/13/happens-australia-wins-eurovision-song-contest/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|accessdate=13 May 2017|date=13 May 2017}}</ref> Further to the EBU's statement it was confirmed that {{Esccnty|Germany}} and their broadcaster [[Norddeutscher Rundfunk|Norddeutscher Rundfunk (NDR)]] would be the first choice, and {{Esccnty|United Kingdom}}'s broadcaster [[British Broadcasting Corporation|British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC)]] being the back-up hosts should Germany decline.<ref name="Oz-Win"/>
==Participation== ===Incidental participation=== Although not actively participating at the Eurovision Song Contest prior to the 2013 semifinal interval presentation, Australia has appeared in the contest incidentally in a number of ways:
*[[Peter Doyle (singer)|Peter Doyle]] and [[Marty Kristian]], both Australians, represented the United Kingdom as part of [[the New Seekers]], who performed "[[Beg, Steal or Borrow]]" at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1972|1972]] contest in Edinburgh. The song, co-written by Australian [[Tony Cole (musician)|Tony Cole]], finished second with 114 points.<ref name="TL"/> * English-born Australian singer-songwriter [[Olivia Newton-John]] represented the United Kingdom in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1974|1974]] (prior to Australian broadcast of the contest) in Brighton with the song "[[Long Live Love (Olivia Newton-John song)|Long Live Love]]", finishing in 4th place with 14 points.<ref name="TL">{{cite news|last1=Lennon|first1=Troy|title=Aussies hit the high notes at Eurovision|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/aussies-hit-the-high-notes-at-eurovision/news-story/e1606df922c887a92998c8b565ee41ec|accessdate=13 May 2016|agency=The Daily Telegraph|date=11 February 2015}}</ref> *[[John Farrar]], who was born in Melbourne, performed as part of [[the Shadows]] for the United Kingdom at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1975|1975]] contest.<ref name="TL"/> *[[Martin Lee (singer)|Martin Lee]], singer in [[Brotherhood of Man]], which won the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1976|1976]] contest, spent several years of his childhood in Australia.<ref name="TL"/> *Austria paid tribute to Australia in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1977|1977]] in London with their entry "[[Boom Boom Boomerang]]" performed by [[Schmetterlinge]]. The song was considered controversial at the time due to being the first song to openly mock the contest itself. *[[Johnny Logan (singer)|Johnny Logan]], winner of the contest in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1980|1980]] and [[Eurovision Song Contest 1987|1987]] for Ireland (and writer of the winning song for Ireland at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1992|1992]] contest), was born in [[Frankston, Victoria]] in 1954, but moved with his family back to Ireland in 1957 aged 3.<ref name="TL"/> * In [[Eurovision Song Contest 1996|1996 in Oslo, Norway]], Australian singer [[Gina G]] represented the United Kingdom with her performance of "[[Ooh Aah... Just a Little Bit]]".<ref name="TL"/> *[[Jane Comerford]], who was born in [[Newcastle, New South Wales]], performed in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2006|2006]] contest for Germany as a part of [[Texas Lightning]] with the song "[[No No Never]]", which took 14th place and 36 points.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McCathie|first1=Andrew|title=Australian singer strikes a blow for Eurovision|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/music/australian-singer-strikes-a-blow-for-eurovision/2006/03/17/1142582525420.html|accessdate=13 May 2016|agency=The Age|date=18 March 2006}}</ref> *Australians [[Craig Porteils]] and [[Cameron Giles-Webb]] co-wrote the song "[[This Is Our Night]]" which was performed by [[Sakis Rouvas]] for Greece at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2009|2009]] contest.<ref name="TL"/> *Katrina Noorbergen, an Australian living in Berlin, co-wrote the song "[[A Million Voices (song)|A Million Voices]]" which was performed by [[Polina Gagarina]] for Russia at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2015|2015]] contest. She also performed as one of Gagarina's backing singers in the contest.<ref name="JM"/> *Tonino Speciale, who grew up in [[Western Sydney]], co-wrote the song "[[Black Smoke (song)|Black Smoke]]" which was performed by [[Ann Sophie]] for Germany at the 2015 contest.<ref name="JM">{{cite news|last1=Moran|first1=Jonathan|title=Songwriter Katrina Noorbergen was part of Australia’s growing presence at Eurovision|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/songwriter-katrina-noorbergen-was-part-of-australias-growing-presence-at-eurovision/news-story/805119110ad3c41a5caa003155631537|accessdate=13 May 2016|agency=The Daily Telegraph|date=26 May 2015}}</ref> *[[Mary-Jean O'Doherty]], an American-born and half-Australian opera singer, performed as part of the group [[Genealogy (band)|Genealogy]] for Armenia at the 2015 contest.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Vincent|first1=Peter|title=Eurovision 2015: Australian Mary-Jean O'Doherty is a rival country's secret weapon|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/eurovision-2015-australian-maryjean-odoherty-is-a-rival-countrys-secret-weapon-20150313-142v6r.html#ixzz48Z35ONvK|accessdate=13 May 2016|agency=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=13 March 2015}}</ref> *[[Anja Nissen]], who is from the [[Blue Mountains (New South Wales)|Blue Mountains]] of New South Wales but is the child of Danish parents, represented Denmark at the 2017 contest in Kiev, finishing in 20th place with 77 points. The song, "[[Where I Am (song)|Where I Am]]", was co-written by Australian songwriters [[Angel Tupai]] and Michael D'Arcy.<ref>{{cite news|last1=AAP|title=Eurovision 2017: Anja Nissen second Australian into final|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/arts/music/eurovision-2017-anja-nissen-second-australian-into-final/news-story/1c57aec06a13d4f8caf527f89206a50b|accessdate=13 May 2017|agency=The Australian|date=12 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://eurovoix.com/2017/02/25/denmark-selects-anja-nissen-for-the-eurovision-song-contest-2017/|title=DENMARK: SELECTS ANJA NISSEN FOR THE EUROVISION SONG CONTEST 2017|date=25 February 2017|publisher=Eurovoix|website=eurovoix.com|last=Granger|first=Anthony}}</ref>
====2013 pre-recorded presentation==== Australia's first appearance in the international broadcast of the Eurovision Song Contest occurred on 14 May 2013 during the first semi-final in Malmö, Sweden. A short pre-recorded video titled "Greetings from Australia" (also referred to as "Why Australia Loves Eurovision"), submitted by SBS and hosted by Julia Zemiro, was broadcast during the interval acts.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/australias-loyal-fandom-earns-eurovision-nod-20130516-2jnu5.html | title = Australia's loyal fandom earns Eurovision nod | website = The Sydney Morning Herald | access-date = 2016-02-27 }}</ref> This presentation marked 30 years of broadcasting the Eurovision Song Contest in Australia, and was preceded the week leading up to the contest by a locally broadcast documentary, also hosted by Zemiro, detailing her love of [[ABBA]], titled ''Road to Eurovision''.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=australia_2012_coverage_a_big_success | title = Australia: 2012 coverage a big success | website = Eurovision.tv | language = en-GB | access-date = 2016-02-27 }}</ref>
====2014 interval act==== On 24 March 2014, the Danish broadcaster [[DR (broadcaster)|DR]] gave permission to SBS to perform as an interval act in the second semi-final of [[Eurovision Song Contest 2014]]. One day later, on 25 March, [[Jessica Mauboy]] was internally selected to perform.<ref>{{cite web|last=Storvik-Green|first=Simon|title=Australian superstar to sing at Eurovision|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=australian_superstar_to_sing_at_eurovision|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|website=Eurovision.tv|accessdate=11 February 2015|date=25 March 2014}}</ref> On 8 May 2014, Mauboy sang her song "[[Sea of Flags]]" in the second semi-final.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/jessica-mauboy-performs-at-eurovision-song-contest-20140509-zr78z.html|title=Jessica Mauboy performs at Eurovision Song Contest|website=smh.com.au|publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|last=Vincent|first=Peter|date=9 May 2014|accessdate=11 February 2015}}</ref>
===2015 debut=== {{main|Australia in the Eurovision Song Contest 2015}} SBS made the country's debut at the 2015 Contest with the song "[[Tonight Again]]" a song written and performed by [[Guy Sebastian]]. Although Australia is outside the [[European Broadcasting Area]], the [[European Broadcasting Union]] and Austrian host broadcaster [[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF]] decided to permit an Australian entry to commemorate the 60th Contest. The special circumstances surrounding Australia's entry and "to not reduce the chances" of the semi-final participants led the organisers to allow Australia to compete directly in the grand final without pre-qualification.<ref>{{cite web|title=Australia participate in the 60th Eurovision|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=australia_to_participate_in_the_2015_eurovision_song_contest|publisher=EBU|website=Eurovision.tv|accessdate=11 February 2015|date=10 February 2015}}</ref> The 2015 Australian jury consisted of [[Amanda Pelman]] (Chair), [[Richard Wilkins (TV presenter)|Richard Wilkins]], [[Danielle Spencer (Australian actress)|Danielle Spencer]] and [[Jake Stone (singer)|Jake Stone]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Australian Eurovision Jury|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/programs/eurovision/rate-and-vote/australian-eurovision-jury|website=SBS Eurovision|publisher=SBS|accessdate=15 May 2016|date=1 May 2015}}</ref>
===2016=== {{main|Australia in the Eurovision Song Contest 2016}} Although Australia's participation in 2015 was announced as a one-off event, it was confirmed on 17 November 2015 that Australia would participate in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016|2016 contest]]. Unlike in 2015, Australia did not receive automatic qualification.<ref>{{cite web|title=Australia To Return To The Eurovision Song Contest|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=australia_to_return_to_the_eurovision_song_contest|publisher=EBU|accessdate=17 November 2015}}</ref> On 7 October 2015, it was announced that Australia would make its debut at the [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2015]] after SBS was invited to perform in the contest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.junioreurovision.tv/page/blog?id=australia_joins_to_make_it_super_17_at_junior_eurovision_in_sofia|title=Australia joins to make it 'Super 17' at Junior Eurovision in Sofia!|website=junioreurovision.tv|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|last=Fisher|first=Luke James|accessdate=7 October 2015|date=7 October 2015}}</ref> The 2016 Australian jury consisted of [[Monica Trapaga]] (Chair), [[Shannon Noll]], [[Myf Warhurst]], [[James Mathison]] and [[Craig Porteils]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Australia’s Eurovision 2016 jury and spokesperson is revealed!|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/programs/eurovision/article/2016/04/29/australias-eurovision-2016-jury-and-spokesperson-revealed|website=SBS Eurovision|publisher=SBS|accessdate=15 May 2016|date=2 May 2016}}</ref> The Australian candidate for the contest was Dami Im.
===2017=== {{main|Australia in the Eurovision Song Contest 2017}} Australia continued its participation at the 2017 contest following their success the previous year.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jordan|first1=Paul|title=43 countries to participate in Eurovision 2017|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=43_countries_to_participate_in_eurovision_2017|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=31 October 2016|date=31 October 2016}}</ref> On 7 March 2017 at the Paris Cat Jazz Club in the city of [[Melbourne|Melbourne, Australia]], SBS announced former ''[[The X Factor (Australian TV series)|X Factor Australia]]'' winner [[Isaiah Firebrace]] as Australia's entry into the 62nd instalment of the contest. With the song "[[Don't Come Easy]]", Isaiah participated in the first semi-final on 9 May, then the finals on 13 May in which Australia placed 9th.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/guide/article/2017/03/07/isaiah-firebrace-will-represent-australia-2017-eurovision-song-contest|title=Isaiah Firebrace represented Australia at the 2017 Eurovision Song Contest and placed 9th |work=Guide|access-date=2017-03-24|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-03-24|title=Eurovision Song Contest 2017|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Eurovision_Song_Contest_2017&oldid=771883720|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref> The 2017 Australian jury consisted of [[Lucy Durack]], Natasha Cupitt, Steven Capaldo, Jackie Loeb and Peter Hayward.<ref>{{cite news|title=SBS announce Australia’s 2017 Eurovision Jury members|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/guide/article/2017/05/01/sbs-announce-australias-2017-eurovision-jury-members|accessdate=11 May 2018|agency=SBS News|date=8 May 2017}}</ref>
===2018=== {{main|Australia in the Eurovision Song Contest 2018}} Australia competed in the 2018 contest, selecting [[Jessica Mauboy]] as the artist to represent the country.<ref name="AUconfirmed">{{cite web|url=http://tvtonight.com.au/2017/08/australia-confirmed-for-eurovision-2018.html|title=Australia confirmed for Eurovision 2018!|date=24 August 2017|accessdate=24 August 2017|work=TV Tonight|first=David|last=Knox}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://wiwibloggs.com/2017/12/11/jessica-mauboy-australia-eurovision-2018/203845/|title=SBS confirms Jessica Mauboy will represent Australia at Eurovision 2018 with her song “We got Love”|date=2017-12-11|work=wiwibloggs|access-date=2017-12-11|language=en-US}}</ref> The 2018 Australian jury comprised [[Richard Wilkins (TV presenter)|Richard Wilkins]] (Chair), [[Zan Rowe]], [[Jordan Raskopoulos]], [[L-FRESH the Lion]] and Millie Millgate.<ref>{{cite news|title=Meet Australia's 2018 Eurovision jury and Australian spokesperson|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/programs/eurovision/article/2018/04/30/meet-australias-2018-eurovision-jury-and-australian-spokesperson|accessdate=11 May 2018|agency=SBS News|date=30 April 2018}}</ref> Although this continued Australia's track record of perfect attendance in the final (a record it now only shares with Ukraine), it was the first instance of them not finishing in the top ten, ending in twentieth place with 99 points (only nine of which came from the televote, the first time Australia finished last in the televote).
===2019=== It was announced that for the first time, 2019 will provide Australians the opportunity to choose their Eurovision representative. The ''Eurovision - Australia Decides'' national final will take place on 9 February 2019, with a 50/50 say between an Australian jury and a televote to determine who will represent Australia at the 2019 contest in Tel Aviv, Israel. ''Eurovision: Australia Decides'' will be hosted in [[Gold Coast, Queensland]] by [[Myf Warhurst]] and [[Joel Creasey]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.sbs.com.au/programs/eurovision/article/2018/09/21/Eurovision-Australia-Decides-2019 |title=We’re opening our song submission for Eurovision 2019! |work=[[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]] |date= October 14, 2018|accessdate=November 3, 2018}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Use Indian English|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox media franchise |title=''Chander Pahar'' |image= |caption= ''Chander Pahar'' film poster |creator=[[Bibhutibhushan Bandyopadhyay]] |origin=''[[Chander Pahar]]'' |books= |novels=''[[Chander Pahar]]'' |comics= ''[[Moon Mountain]]''
''Amazon Obhijaan'' |magazines= |strips= |films=''[[Chander Pahar (film)|Chander Pahar]]''
''[[Amazon Obhijaan]]'' |tv= |plays= |musicals= |games= |rpgs= |vgs= |radio= ''Chander Pahar'' ([[Sunday Suspense]]) |soundtracks= |music= |toys= |otherlabel1= |otherdata1= |otherlabel2= |otherdata2= |otherlabel3= |otherdata3= }} '''''Chander Pahar''''' is an [[India]]n [[Bengali language]] franchise consisting of novels, graphic novels and a film series. The original work is a 1937 novel{{cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Bandyopadhyay,_Bibhutibhushan|title=Bandyopadhyay, Bibhutibhushan|work=banglapedia.org}} named ''[[Chander Pahar]]'', written by [[Bibhutibhushan Bandyopadhyay]].{{cite book|author=Sunīlakumāra Caṭṭopādhyāẏa|title=Bibhutibhushan Bandopadhyaya|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Kp8WZ5a34NQC&pg=PA17|accessdate=5 July 2012|date=1 January 1994|publisher=Sahitya Akademi|isbn=978-81-7201-578-7|pages=17–}} It was translated to English in 2002 by Santanu Sinha Choudhuri and Pradeep Kumar Sinha, published by Orient Blackswan. The English version of the novel was titled ''Mountain of the Moon''. Bandyopadhyay’s story was adapted into a [[Moon Mountain|Graphic novel]] and a [[Chander Pahar (film)|live-action film]] in 2013.{{cite news|title=‘Chander Pahar’ promises adventure shots not seen before|url=http://zeenews.india.com/entertainment/regional/chander-pahar-promises-adventure-shots-not-seen-before_146594.html|accessdate=24 November 2013|newspaper=[[Zee News]]}} A sequel to the 2013 film ''[[Amazon Obhijaan]]'', written by the director of the first film [[Kamaleswar Mukherjee]], is released in Christmas 2017.http://timesofindia.com/entertainment/bengali/movies/news/Devs-Amazon-adventure-starts-now/articleshow/52127042.cms ==Novel (1937)== {{main| Chander Pahar}} ===Plot=== This novel tells the story of an ordinary young Bengali man, [[Shankar Roy Chowdhury (character)|Shankar Roy Chowdhury]], as he adventures in [[Africa]] in the years 1909 and 1910. After graduating from college at 20-years-old, his family's financial struggles almost force him take a job in a [[jute]] mill in Shyamnagar — a prospect he absolutely loathes. Because loves the subject of geography, he wants to follow the footsteps of renowned explorers like [[David Livingstone|Livingstone]], [[Mungo Park (explorer)|Mungo Park]], and [[Marco Polo]]. He wants to explore the wilderness, passionate for learning about African forests and animals. By a stroke of luck, he gets a job as a clerk at the [[Uganda Railway]] and rushes to Africa without a second thought. After a few months laying rail tracks, he encounters the first of many dangers in pre-[[World War I]] Africa: a man-eating lion. Later, he takes up a job as station-master in a desolate station amidst the [[Veldt]]s, where he to narrowly escapes a deadly [[black mamba]]. While at this post, Shankar encounters, rescues and nurses Diego Alvarez, a middle-age Portuguese explorer and gold/diamond prospector. Alvarez's arrival becomes a turning point in Shankar's life. While recovering, Alvarez describes his exploits in Africa with his friend Jim Carter. He explains that, lured by the prosepect of a priceless yellow diamond from a Kaafi village chief, Alvarez and Carter searched for these yellow diamond caves, on the Mountain of the Moon (Chander Pahar) in the [[Richtersveld]]. Rumors suggested a mythical monster, the [[Bunyip]], guards the mine. The explorers set off into the dense jungle, much against the villagers' advice, and Carter was gruesomely killed, supposedly by the Bunyip. Shankar, inspired by Alvarez's exploits, resigns from his job and accompanies Alvarez to venture again for the mines. They meet hardships, like a raging [[volcano]]. Eventually, they get lost in the forests where Alvarez is killed by the [[Bunyip]]. Demoralised, Shankar tries to return to civilization. He finds the Bunyip's cave and the diamond mines by accident. Almost getting lost, he finds the remains of the Italian explorer, Attilio Gatti, and learns that the cave is in fact the diamond mine. Leaving, he becomes lost in the deserts of [[Kalahari]] and nearly dies of thirst. Fortunately, he is rescued by a survey team and taken to a hospital in [[Harare|Salisbury]], [[Rhodesia]], from where he sets sail for home. Before going back, he writes his account in a newspaper, earning him money. He names the volcano after Alvarez. He ends the book saying that he will return to the cave one day with a large team, and continue the legacy of Alvarez, Carter, and Gatti. ===Characters=== *[[Shankar Roy Chowdhury (character)|Shankar Roy Chowdhury]] — The hero of the story, a young man from a village in Bengal. He is a smart, brave person who has a penchant for adventures. *[[Diego Alvarez (character)|Diego Alvarez]] — A Portuguese explorer. He is a friend and mentor to Shankar, and together they explore the deepest reaches of [[Richtersveld]] for the Mountain of the Moon. *Jim Carter — A British explorer who was Alvarez's companion in his previous expedition. Alvarez revealed to Shankar that Carter was killed by the [[Bunyip]] while he and Carter were exploring the Mountains of the Moon. *[[Attilio Gatti]] — An Italian explorer. He discovered the diamond mine caves in ''c.'' 1879 but dies in a cave (later discovered by Shankar) on his way back, in the hands of his traitorous followers. ==Graphic Novels== {{Infobox graphic novel |title = Moon Mountain |image = |caption = Cover page of the Graphic novel |alt = |publisher = [[Penguin India]] |date = 15 Feb 2014 |origpublication = |origissues = |transisbn = 9780143332589 |origlanguage = English |writers = [[Bibhutibhushan Bandyopadhyay]]
[[Saurav Mohapatra]] |artist = [[Sayan Mukherjee]] |creator = Bibhutibhushan Bandyopadhyay |pages = 160 }} ===''Moon Mountain'' (2014)=== ''Moon Mountain'' is a 2014 [[Graphic novel]] adapted from [[Bibhutibhushan Bandyopadhyay]]'s classic ''Chander Pahar''. The graphic novel is published by [[Penguin India|Penguin Books India]], has its script written by [[Saurav Mohapatra]] with illustrations by [[Sayan Mukherjee]]{{cite news| url=http://eprahaar.in/bibhutibhushan-classic-chander-pahar-now-as-graphic-novel/ | work=eprahaar.in | title=Bibhutibhushan classic ‘Chander Pahar’ now as graphic novel}}{{cite news| url=http://www.livemint.com/Leisure/hrk1YtnUwhBQRPkkM3duYK/Book-Review--Moon-Mountain.html | work=livemint.com | title=Book Review - Moon Mountain}}{{cite web|url=http://www.penguinbooksindia.com/en/content/moon-mountain|title=Moon Mountain - Penguin Books India|work=penguinbooksindia.com}} ===''Amazon Obhijaan'' (2017)=== ''Amazon Obhijaan'' is a 2017 [[Graphic novel]] based on the [[Amazon Obhijaan|film of the same name]].https://www.outlookindia.com/newsscroll/amazon-obhijaan-graphic-novel-launched/1186534 The graphic novel is written by film's director [[Kamaleswar Mukherjee]], and available in two languages - English and Bengali.http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/amazon-obhijaan-graphic-novel-launched/1/1087602.html The graphic novel acts as a promotional activity for the film. It is released on 11 November 2017.http://www.sangbadpratidin.in/svf-launches-the-amazon-obhijaan-graphic-novel/ ==Films== ===''Chander Pahar'' (2013)=== {{main| Chander Pahar (film)}} A film based on the novel, directed by [[Kamaleshwar Mukherjee]] was released on 20 December 2013 (27 December 2013 in all over India).{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-11-21/news-interviews/35256844_1_bengali-film-kamaleswar-mukherjee-hollywood-film |title=Film on Chander Pahar - Times Of India |publisher=Articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=21 November 2012 |accessdate=22 November 2013}} The film, poorly received by critics and the Bengali audience,{{Citation needed|date = December 2015}} was produced by [[Shree Venkatesh Films]] and has been shot on locations across Africa. It was reportedly being made with a budget of nearly {{INRConvert|150|m}}, making it one of the most expensive in the Bengali film industry. Director Kamaleshwar Mukherjee mentioned ''Chander Pahar'' as his "Dream Project". The film has reportedly incorporated CGI and visual effects at par with Hollywood and Bollywood standards. [[Dev (actor)|Dev]] plays the role of the main protagonist, [[Shankar Roy Chowdhury (character)|Shankar]].{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130109/jsp/entertainment/story_16416937.jsp#.UPPmJmf6OVA | location=Calcutta, India | work=The Telegraph | title=Kamaleshwar Mukherjee's Trip To South Africa For Chander Pahar, Starring Dev | date=9 January 2013}} Most of the other cast members are from South Africa. According to the crew members, it took a considerable time to decide who would play the role of [[Diego Alvarez (character)|Diego Alvarez]], and South African actor [[Gérard Rudolf]] was selected. The first theatrical trailer of the film was released by Shree Venkatesh Films, at the Kolkata Nicco park on 14 November 2013. Shooting locations include [[Kruger National Park]], the mountains of [[Drakensberg]], and the deserts of [[Kalahari]].{{cite news| url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-03-08/news-interviews/37560813_1_black-mamba-dev-shankar | work=The Times of India | title=Kamaleswar's African safari}} ===''Amazon Obhijaan'' (2017)=== {{main|Amazon Obhijaan}} According to a Bengali magazine, director [[Kamaleshwar Mukherjee]] is already penning the script, taking the story forward from where it left and [[Dev (actor)|Dev]] has been quoted as saying that the next location, after the African safari, will be the dense forests of [[Amazon rainforest]].{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/bengali/movies/news/Dev-Kamaleswar-planning-Chander-Pahar-sequel/articleshow/47655129.cms|title=Dev, Kamaleswar planning Chander Pahar sequel!|publisher=''[[The Times of India]]''|accessdate=13 June 2015}} The film has been titled ''Amazon Obhijan''. The story of the film is original, written by [[Kamaleshwar Mukherjee]] with some character reprising their roles from the original ''[[Chander Pahar]]''. Reportedly it will be made with a budget of whopping {{INR}}20 [[crores]].{{cite web|url=http://www.anandabazar.com/entertainment/see-exclusive-shots-from-dev-s-amazon-obhijaan-dgtl-1.396813|title=দেখুন, ‘শঙ্করের অ্যামাজন অভিযান’-এর বিশেষ মুহূর্ত|first=নিজস্ব|last=প্রতিবেদন|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2016}} The shooting of this film has been started from May 2016 and ended in July 2017.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.com/entertainment/bengali/movies/news/Devs-Amazon-adventure-starts-now/articleshow/52127042.cms|title=Dev's Amazon adventure starts now! - Times of India|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2016}} ===''Chander Pahar 3'' (TBA)=== {{main|Shankar's Next Adventure}} A sequel to ''Amazon Obhijaan'' is instantly announced after the release of the film. Commonly referred as ''Shankar's Next Adventure'' the film announced along with 24 more films of 3 upcoming years.https://scroll.in/reel/864939/shree-venkatesh-films-to-roll-out-25-bengali-films-over-next-three-years ===Cast and characters=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" width="100%" |- ! rowspan="2" | Character ! colspan="3" | Film |- ! width:10%;"| ''[[Chander Pahar (film)|Chander Pahar]]''

page.title: Diaz Ayala Cuban and Latin American Popular Music Collection

revision.text:
[[File:FIU Library Logo.jpg|thumbnail|left|FIU Libraries]]
The '''Diaz Ayala Cuban and Latin American Popular Music Collection-FIU''',located in the City of Sweetwater, [[Miami-Dade County]], [[Florida]], is a Special Collection of [[Latin American Music]] donated to [[Florida International University]] Libraries [https://library.fiu.edu/] in 2001 by the Cuban discographer Cristobal Diaz Ayala.
==The Collection==
The Diaz Ayala Cuban and Latin American Popular Music Collection (DAC) is the most extensive publicly available collection of Cuban music in the [[United States]]. It was donated to [[Florida International University]] Libraries in 2001 by the Cuban discographer and Lawyer Cristobal Diaz Ayala.<ref>Latin music donated. (Collections). (2002, September). American Libraries, 33(8), 24.</ref> The archive supports the Florida International University's mission of teaching, research, and service by providing means for the discovery and the pursuit of knowledge. It was started prior to 1960 in Cuba and then restarted in Puerto Rico in 1960. At present the collection comprises approximately 150,000 units.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Format !! Records |- | Books and magazines || 5,000 |- | Clippings || 18,000 |- | LPs || 45,000 |- | 78rpm records || 15,000 |- | 45rpm records || 2,500 |- | CDs || 5,000 |- | Photos || 3,000 |- | Videocassettes || 2,000 |- | Cassettes || 4,000 |- | Sheet music, catalogs, brochures || 8,000 |- | Folders("libretas", with chips)and indexes || 500 |- | Copies of RCA Victor's recording session history cards || 41,000 |- | Billboards and lobby cards of Mexican movies || 150 |- |}
==History== This initiative was started prior to 1960 by Mr. Diaz-Ayala. The collection contains more than 150,000 items in total and is currently being expanded.<ref>Ratliff, B. (2001, October 24). Cristobal Diaz Ayala Bequeaths His Huge Archive of Cuban Sound. New York Times, p. E1.</ref> It was recently appraised at over one million of dollars. The materials collected include a variety of formats such as books, [[LP’s]], [[78rpm]], [[45rpm]], CDs, photos, videos, cassettes, sheet music, catalogs, [[RCA Victor]]<ref>http://victor.library.ucsb.edu/index.php/resources/detail/58</ref> cards, and posters, among others. The collection does not only include materials from [[Latin America]] musicians but also from artists from all around the world that have a connection to Latin roots.
Rare and valuable items recorded during the pre-revolutionary Cuba are part of the DAC.<ref>Diaz-Ayala, C. (2007). Music and Revolution: Cultural Change in Socialist Cuba. Journal of Latin American Studies, 39(2), 431</ref> Under this category, it is possible to find cylinders, pianola rolls, 78 rpm, and rare books. Fragile 78 rpm records have been digitized in order to preserve them and keep them available for academic and research purposes. At the moment, it is possible to retrieve information about all the 78 rpm records as well as part of the Cuban and Puerto Rican LPs recordings through the collection metadata available at [http://latinpop.fiu.edu DAC website].
More than 350 interviews were incorporated into the DAC collection. Renowned performers, composers, and musicians such as [[Alfredo "Chocolate" Armenteros]], [[Abelardo Barroso]], [[Bola de Nieve]], and [[Isolina Carrillo]] are part of these conversations. The interviews contain significant and non-published information about how the groups were created, when and by whom, names and history about music companies, artist’s biographical information, and others. It provides researchers with the opportunity to learn more about personal experiences and anecdotes of the artists, groups, entrepreneurs, etc.
The largest part of the [[magnetic tape]] collection corresponds to [[Sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] made from 78’ discs that are not contained in the collection or were never recorded in any other format, not only from Cuban music<ref>[[Music of Cuba]]</ref> but also from other Latin American countries. Today, the FIU libraries are trying to fund a project that allows the digitization of magnetic tapes, since most of the tapes have more than 40 years of existence, which places them in a dangerous situation. The risk of demagnetization increases daily, since the estimated tape life expectancy ranges from less than ten years to a couple of decades.
==The Donor== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Cristobal Diaz-Ayala.jpg|thumbnail|right|Cristobal Diaz-Ayala]] -->
Cristobal Diaz Ayala was born on June 20, 1930 in Havana, [[Cuba]]. He studied at the [[University of Havana]], where he attended the School of Journalism, obtained a degree in Social Sciences, and graduated from the Faculty of Law. Diaz Ayala immigrated to Puerto Rico in 1960, and was admitted by the Puerto Rican Law Association in 1966. He has published hundreds of articles and more than a dozen books. Among his most prominent works and cited by relevant researchers we can find ''Música cubana del Areito a la [[Nueva Trova]] (1981); Si te quieres por el pico divertir: historia del [[pregón]] musical latinoamericano (1988); Música cubana del areito al rap cubano (1993); Cuando salí de La Habana: 1898-1997: cien años de música cubana por el mundo (1998); La marcha de Los Jíbaros 1898-1997 (1998); Cuba canta y baila: discografía de la música cubana, primer volumen: 1898-1925 (1994) y segundo volumen: de 1925 a la actualidad (2005); Los contrapuntos de la música cubana (2006), San Juan-New York: discografía de la música puertorriqueña (2009),<ref>Moore, R. (2010). Cristobal Diaz Ayala. San Juan-New York: Discografia de la musica puertorriquena 1900-1942. Latin American Music Review, 31(2), 273.</ref> Oh Cuba Hermosa Volumen 1 y 2''. Diaz Ayala has also compiled and published two major selections of the most representative music of Cuba (100 Canciones cubanas del Milenio) and [[Puerto Rico]].
==The Discography==
Cuba Canta y Baila is a [[discography]] written by Cristóbal Díaz Ayala, available online at no cost and without access restrictions. The Discography is organized in alphabetical order by last name. It has been published in two volumes. Volume one contains information related to music and musicians from 1898 to 1925. Volume two includes information from 1925 to 1960. The discography does not only contain a list of discs recorded by specific artists, but also biographic information of performers, musicians, [[composers]], among others.
==Copyright== The Sound and Image Department at the FIU Libraries does not claim [[copyright]] for any item in the collection. Copies for transmission, broadcast, reproduction, publishing, etc., not covered by fair use, require the written permission of the copyright owners. The user assumes all responsibility for clearing reproduction rights and fees as well as any infringement of United States copyright law (U.S. Code, Title 17) Authorized materials used for publication, exhibition, or display must be credited to "The Diaz-Ayala Cuban and Latin American Popular Music Collection, Florida International University Library". The Sound and Image Department and the FIU Libraries specifically disclaim any and all liability for any loss or damages which may be incurred, directly or indirectly, as a result of the use of the information in the DAC, or for any omissions or errors contained in this collection.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * The Diaz Ayala Cuban and Latin American Popular Music Collection http://latinpop.fiu.edu/ * DAC Social Media https://es-es.facebook.com/pages/Diaz-Ayala-Cuban-and-Latin-American-Music-Collection-at-FIU-Libraries/534773596559898 * Cuba Nostalgia Exhibit - Celia Cruz 200_ http://latinpop.fiu.edu/exhibit/timeline/exhibit2.html * Revista de Música Latino Americana http://utpress.utexas.edu/index.php/journals/latin-american-music-review
[[Category:Cuban-American culture in Florida]] [[Category:Hispanic and Latino American culture in Florida]] [[Category:Music libraries]] [[Category:Music organizations based in the United States]]

page.title: Don't Take It Personally, Babe, It Just Ain't Your Story

revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox video game |title = don't take it personally, babe, it just ain't your story |italic title = force |image = DonttakeitpersonallyTitle.png{{!}}border |caption = Title screen |developer = Love Conquers All Games |designer = [[Christine Love (writer)|Christine Love]] |engine = [[Ren'Py]] |publisher = |released = April 4, 2011 |genre = [[Visual novel]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |platforms=[[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[Mac OS X]], [[Linux]] }}
'''''don't take it personally, babe, it just ain't your story''''' is a 2011 [[indie game|indie video game]] by [[Christine Love (writer)|Christine Love]]. Intended as a spiritual sequel to Love's ''[[Digital: A Love Story]]'', the game was developed over the course of a month and was released as a free download on April 4, 2011. ''Don't take it personally'' is a [[visual novel]], with the majority of the plot taking place outside of the player's control except for key decisions. It follows a new high school literature teacher in 2027 over the course of a semester, with the ability to see private messages between students at any time without their knowledge. It deals with themes of privacy and relationships in the future. The game was received positively, with critics praising the interplay between the [[metafiction]]al elements of the story and those of the game itself, with special acknowledgment reserved for the writing.
==Gameplay== [[File:DonttakeitpersonallyScreenshot.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A screenshot of the game, showing an Amie conversation thread between several of the students during a conversation in the classroom with Charlotte.]] ''Don't take it personally'' is a [[visual novel]], or [[interactive fiction]] game where the majority of the story is told through still images of the speaking characters in front of [[anime]]-style backgrounds with text overlaid. The player's viewpoint follows one character, the teacher in a school, with the player seeing his thoughts as well as his and the other characters' statements. The player advances the conversations the teacher is in or witnesses at will, but cannot go backwards and has little control over what any of the characters, including the teacher, are saying except at a few key moments. At these points, the player is presented with two or three choices for what the teacher says; which option is chosen can change what path the plot takes, in either a minor or major way.<ref name="RPSreview"/>
In a departure from most visual novels the player can also see, at any time, the equivalent of texts and [[Facebook]] postings between the students on a school [[Social networking service|social network]] called AmieConnect (often shortened to "Amie"), as well as conversation threads on a [[4chan]]-like [[imageboard]] that serve as foreshadowing for future plot points. These extra conversations take place in parallel to in-person conversations between characters, occasionally at the same time; the player is notified anytime a new text message or post is made. A single playthrough of the game takes "over an hour".<ref name="PMreview"/>
==Scenario==
===Setting=== The game is set in a private high school in Ontario, in 2027. The player follows a new 11th-grade literature teacher at the school, John Rook, who has recently had his second divorce and is undergoing, in his words, a "bizarre midlife crisis" that has led him to quit his career in computers and become a teacher.<ref name="GAMEmidlife"/> The students in his class are Arianna Belle-Essai, Kendall Flowers, Taylor Gibson, Charlotte Grewal, Isabella Hart, Nolan Striukas, and Akira Yamazaki. Rook and all of the students have school-issued computers, which the students use to communicate between each other in private and public messages. Rook, and therefore the player, can see all of the messages that the students send, even the private ones; the school administration has told Rook that it is for monitoring online bullying, and that he is not to let anyone know that he can see students' private messages.<ref name="GAMEspy"/>
===Plot=== Soon after the game opens, the player learns that Kendall and Charlotte have just broken up out of a lesbian relationship,<ref name="GAMEkcbreak"/> while a few weeks prior Taylor and Nolan had broken up out of a heterosexual relationship.<ref name="GAMEtnbreak"/> Arianna develops a crush on the teacher, which in the player's first decision point Rook can reciprocate or not.<ref name="GAMEarc1"/> Akira soon comes out as gay, finding to his dismay that everyone else already knew.<ref name="GAMEakgay"/> He then attempts to enter into a relationship with Nolan, who is unsure how to respond;<ref name="GAMEantry"/> Rook can encourage him to try it out or let him decide on his own, but he enters a relationship with Akira regardless.<ref name="GAMEngay"/>
The next day, Isabella misses a meeting she set up with Rook, and does not return to the class. Through Amie texts and wall posts, the other students insinuate that she committed suicide,<ref name="GAMEidead1"/> while the school is unable to provide Rook with any contact information for her.<ref name="GAMEidead2"/> Class continues without her, and a little while later Arianna, if the player rejected her earlier in the game, makes another attempt to have a relationship with Rook. The player may choose to accept or reject her again.<ref name="GAMEarc2"/> Through Amie, Rook learns that both Charlotte and Kendall wish to resume their relationship, and can influence Charlotte to try again or not, which changes whether or not they get back together.<ref name="GAMEcc"/> Taylor jealously and unsuccessfully tries to drive a wedge between Nolan and Akira.<ref name="GAMEnabreak"/>
As the end of term approaches, Rook begins getting strange emails about Isabella's death, and begins seeing [[shinigami]] figures. Upset by these occurrences, when Akira's mother asks to speak to him concerning misuses of Amie, he assumes that she has found out that he is spying on the students' conversations.<ref name="GAMEend1"/> When he meets her, he finds that Isabella is alive and had simply moved away; the students made it look like she was dead via Amie as a prank that got out of control. Furthermore, they already knew that he could see their messages; Akira's mother explains that the students have no idea of online privacy, having always had technology like Amie, and assumed that anything they put online—even "private" messages—might be read by anyone.<ref name="GAMEend2"/> The game ends with Rook having a casual lunch with the students, a date with Arianna, or neither, depending on the choices made during the game by the player.
==Development== ''Don't take it personally'' was developed over the course of a month, and was released as a free download on April 4, 2011.<ref name="CLrelease"/> It was written and developed by [[Christine Love (writer)|Christine Love]], with artwork made for the game by Auro-Cyanide, artwork licensed from Tokudaya and Kimagure After, and with music licensed from Rengoku Teien and propanmode.<ref name="CLcredits"/> It was created using the [[Ren'Py]] engine. It was Love's longest game to date, and her first attempt at a game with a branching storyline.<ref name="CLrelease"/> It was intended as "a spiritual sequel of sorts" to ''[[Digital: A Love Story]]'', a 2010 game by Love.<ref name="CLgamemain"/> The game was made for NaNoRenO (National [[Dating sim|Ren'ai]] Game Writing Month), a month-long contest in the vein of [[National Novel Writing Month]] (NaNoWriMo) where developers attempt to create a visual novel in one month.<ref name="CLgamemain"/> Love's favorite character to write was Kendall.<ref name="CLfinal"/>
==Reception== ''Don't take it personally'' was chosen as a "freeware game pick" by IndieGames's Michael Rose, who said that it was worth playing through multiple times in order to see the different paths the story takes depending on the player's choices.<ref name="IGreview"/> ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' gave the visual novel the award for "Best Script" in its video game awards of 2011, stating that "Love's layered narrative of a high school teacher embroiled in his student's worries goes places most mainstream video games wouldn't dare."<ref name="TDTaward"/> Pete Davidson of ''[[GamePro]]'' noted the game as an example of the "creativity" missing in many large-budget titles, and praised the story, calling Love "a writer first and a game developer second."<ref name="GPreview"/> Alec Meer of [[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]] described the game as "a game about love, sex and the internet" that was "capable of being profoundly moving" and was about "what it is to feel like someone's kicked me straight in the heart".<ref name="RPSreview"/> He praised Love's ability to use dialogue to effect an emotional response, though he noted that the game seemed to lose some of its impact in the final chapters and felt that the use of the "12chan" threads as a [[Greek chorus]] was "perhaps a meta-layer too far".<ref name="RPSreview"/>
Aaron Poppleton of [[PopMatters]] called the game "a meditation on privacy in the modern age" and "one of the more thoughtful games to come out in a long time." He criticized the art direction of the game, saying that the limitation of creating the game in a month led to poor artwork and an unpolished presentation that let down the possibilities of the story. He did note that the story and writing of the game made the downsides of the game "almost entirely a moot point", and that it is a very strong game.<ref name="PMreview"/> Pete Davidson of ''[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]'', in an article about the treatment of sexuality in video games, called out the game as an example of a game that used sexual themes maturely to explore love and relationships.<ref name="PCWarticle"/> [[Emily Short]] of [[Gamasutra]], in a discussion about the game, said that it was definitely worth playing and full of "charming characters, colorful dialogue, and important questions", but criticized the uneven exploration of issues regarding privacy versus [[personal boundaries]]. She said that the game's lack of focus on Rook's issues with [[personal boundaries|personal]] and [[professional boundaries]] was a weakness in the story, given that the distinction between boundaries and privacy was crucial to the plot.<ref name="GSdiscuss"/> Love collated common criticisms and reviews of the game on her blog, summarizing that while it was less praised than ''Digital: A Love Story'', most players seemed to like the way she wrote the relationships and overall story. There was a consensus, however, that her portrayal of Rook was weak and that many players seemed to miss both that he was intended to be "an absolutely awful teacher" and that the potential relationship with Arianna was intended to be creepy and make the player feel bad. She also noted that her use of licensed artwork detracted from the game's potential in comparison to the reaction to the custom works.<ref name="CLreviews"/>
