revision.comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/42.110.217.185|42.110.217.185]] ([[User talk:42.110.217.185|talk]]): We're not going to list translations into all languages. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
[[Image:Deck of cards used in the game piquet.jpg|right|thumb|Standard 32 card deck of the Paris pattern.]] '''French playing cards''' (''jeu de cartes'') are [[playing cards|cards]] that use the French [[Suit (cards)|suits]] of {{lang|fr|trèfles}} (clovers or clubs {{Clubs}}), {{lang|fr|carreaux}} (tiles or diamonds {{Diams}}), {{lang|fr|cœurs}} (hearts {{Hearts}}), and {{lang|fr|piques}} (pikes or spades {{Spades}}). Each suit contains three [[face cards]]; the {{lang|fr|valet}} ([[jack (playing card)|knave or jack]]), the {{lang|fr|dame}} ([[queen (playing card)|lady or queen]]), and the {{lang|fr|roi}} ([[king (playing card)|king]]). Aside from these aspects, decks can include a wide variety of regional and national patterns which often have [[stripped deck|different deck sizes]]. In comparison to [[Spanish playing cards|Spanish]], [[Italian playing cards|Italian]], [[German playing cards|German]], and [[Swiss playing cards]], French cards are the most widespread due to the geopolitical, commercial, and cultural influence of France and the United Kingdom in the past two centuries. Other reasons for their popularity were the simplicity of the suit insignia, which simplifies mass production, and the popularity of [[whist]] and [[contract bridge]]. ==History== Playing cards arrived in Europe from [[Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)|Mamluk Egypt]] around 1370 and were already reported in France in 1377. The French suit insignia was derived from German suits around 1480. Between the transition from the suit of bells to tiles there was a suit of crescents.{{cite book|last1=Dummett|first1=Michael|title=The Game of Tarot|date=1980|publisher=Duckworth|location=London|pages=10-30}} One of the most distinguishing features of the French cards is the queen. Mamluk cards and their derivatives, the Latin suited and German suited cards, all have three male face cards. Queens began appearing in Italian [[tarot]] decks in the mid-15th century and some German decks replaced two kings with queens. While other decks abandoned the queen in non-tarot decks, the French kept them and dropped the [[Knight (playing card)|knight]] as the middle face card. Face card design was heavily influenced by Spanish cards that used to circulate in France. One of the most obvious traits inherited from Spain are the standing kings; kings from Italian, Portuguese, or Germanic cards are seated. Spanish-suited cards are still used in France, mostly in [[Northern Catalonia]], and [[Brittany]] and the [[Vendée]] with the latter two using the archaic [[Aluette]] cards. In the 19th century, corner indices and rounded corners were added and cards became reversible, relieving players from having to flip face cards right side up. The index for [[ace]]s and face cards usually follow the local language but many decks of the Paris pattern use the numeral "1" for aces. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;margin:1em" align=left |- |German |Hearts
[[Image:Bay herz.svg|35x35px|center]] |Bells
[[Image:Bay schellen.svg|35x35px|center]] |Acorns
[[Image:Bay eichel.svg|35x35px|center]] |Leaves
[[Image:Bay gras.svg|35x35px|center]] |- |French |Hearts
[[Image:SuitHearts.svg|35x35px|center]] |Tiles
[[Image:SuitDiamonds.svg|35x35px|center]] |Clovers
[[Image:SuitClubs.svg|35x35px|center]] |Pikes
[[Image:SuitSpades.svg|35x35px|center]] |} File:15thCenturySpanishCardDeck.jpg|Deck celebrating the [[union of Brittany and France]] with Spanish suits but has queens instead of knights (Antoine de Logiriera of Toulouse, c.1500). File:French playing cards with suit of crescents.jpg|A transitional deck with suits of hearts and crescents (François Clerc of Lyon, late 15th century). File:Kings-comparison.jpg|French Rouen pattern on the left, Spanish Toledo pattern on the right. File:Aluette card deck - Grimaud - 1858-1890 - King of Coins.jpg|King of coins from [[Aluette]], a Spanish-suited deck still in use in France. It is related to the Toledo pattern. {{clear}} ==Current standard patterns== The French suited deck has spawned many regional variations known as standard patterns based on their artwork and deck size. The Paris pattern was heavily exported throughout continental Europe which is why most French-suited patterns share a similar appearance. The English pattern, based on the extinct Rouennais pattern, is the most well known pattern in the world. Note that patterns do not factor in [[Joker (playing card)|Jokers]] as they are a very recent addition which leads to every manufacturer making their own trademarked depiction of this card. Almost all 52-card packs produced in the present will contain at least two jokers unless otherwise noted. ===Paris pattern=== {{Multiple image| |total_width=450 |image1=Paris Portrait card deck - 1740-1751 - King of Hearts.jpg |image2=French Portrait card deck - 1813 - King of Hearts.jpg |image3=French Portrait card deck - 1827 - King of Hearts.jpg |image4=King of hearts fr.svg |footer=Charles, King of Hearts in the ''portrait officiel''}} The Paris pattern came to dominate in France around 1780 and became known as the {{lang|fr|portrait officiel}}. From the 19th century to 1945, the appearance of the cards used for domestic consumption was regulated by the French government. All cards were produced on watermarked paper made by the state to show payment of the [[stamp duty|stamp tax]].[http://i-p-c-s.org/pattern/bgp.html Belgian-Genoese pattern] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 5 February 2016. The most common deck sold in France is the 32-card deck with the 2 to 6 removed and 1s as the index for aces. 52-card decks are also popular. The French have a unique habit of associating their face cards with historic or mythical personages which survives only in the ''portrait officiel''.{{cite journal|last1=Berry|first1=John|title=The History of the Paris Pattern|journal=[[The Playing-Card]]|date=1984|volume=13|issue=1|pages=1-23}}
{| class="wikitable" |+ !Rank/Suit !Spades !Hearts !Diamonds !Clubs |- |'''King''' |[[David]] |[[Charles]]possibly [[Charlemagne]], or [[Charles VII of France|Charles VII]], in which case Rachel (see below) would be the pseudonym of his mistress, [[Agnès Sorel]] |[[Julius Caesar|Cesar]] |[[Alexander the Great|Alexandre]] |- |'''Queen''' |[[Pallas Athena (goddess)|Pallas]] |[[Book of Judith|Judith]] |[[Rachel]]either biblical, historical (see Charles above) |[[Argine]]possibly an [[anagram]] of ''regina'', which is [[Latin]] for queen, or perhaps [[Argia (mythology)|Argea]], wife of Polybus and mother of [[Argo|Argus]] |- |'''Jack''' |[[Ogier the Dane|Hogier]]a knight of Charlemagne |[[La Hire]]comrade-in-arms to Joan of Arc, and member of [[Charles VII of France|Charles VII]]'s court |[[Hector]] |[[Lancelot]] since 1813, from 1613–1813 this card carried the manufacturer's name, before 1613 it was [[Judas Maccabeus]] |}
{{clear}} ====Belgian-Genoese and Piedmontese patterns==== [[File:King of hearts (Belgian pattern).jpg|thumb|100px|Belgian pattern king of hearts]] The '''Belgian-Genoese pattern''' is very similar to its Parisian parent and is basically an export version not subject to France's domestic stamp tax.[http://i-p-c-s.org/pattern/bgp.html Belgian-Genoese pattern] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 5 February 2016.Pollett, Andrea. [http://a_pollett.tripod.com/cards21.htm Belgian and Genoese cards] at Andy's Playing Cards. Retrieved 5 February 2016. The jack of clubs has a triangular shield bearing the coat of arms of the former [[Spanish Netherlands]], face cards are unnamed, and blue is usually replaced with green in the portraits. The diagonal dividing line also lacks the beads. When the [[Ottoman Empire]] relaxed the ban against playing cards, Belgian type cards flooded their territory and is now found throughout the Balkans, North Africa, and the Middle East. They are also commonly found in France's former colonies. Within Belgium, the Francophone [[Walloons]] are the primary users of this pattern, the [[Flemish people|Flemish]] prefer the Dutch pattern. This is the second most common pattern in the world after the English pattern. Belgian decks come in either 32 or 52 cards like in France. Genoese type cards are identical to Belgian ones but lack corner indices. They come in 36 (no 2s to 5s), 40 (no 8s to 10s), or 52 card decks. The '''Piedmontese pattern''' is similar to the Genoese packs but its face cards have a horizontal instead of diagonal dividing line and the aces are found in a decorative garland.[http://www.altacarta.com/english/collect/suits/french/piemontesi.html The Piemont Pattern] at Alta Carta. Retrieved 18 February 2016.Wintle, Simon. [http://www.wopc.co.uk/italy/piedmont Piedmont Type] at the World of Playing Cards. Retrieved 20 January 2018. They also come in the same number of cards as Genoese ones. The Piedmontese pattern was once used in neighboring [[Savoy]] as both were [[Savoyard state|previously united]] until France annexed the latter in 1860. A 78 card tarot version of the Piedmontese pattern, complete with knights, [[The Fool (Tarot card)|the fool]], a suit of [[Trump (card games)|trumps]] depicting flowers, and corner indices, was printed in 1902 for Savoyard players. It was discontinued some time after 1910 but reproductions have been in print since 1984. The [[Chambéry]] rules that come with the deck are similar to Piedmontese tarot games but the ace ranked between the jack and the 10 like in [[Triomphe]].{{cite book|last1=Dummett|first1=Michael|last2=McLeod|first2=John|title=A History of Games Played with the Tarot Pack Volume I|date=2004|publisher=The Edwin Mellen Press|location=Lewiston|pages=174-178}}{{cite book|last1=Depaulis|first1=Thierry|title=Tarot, jeu et magie|date=1984|publisher=[[Bibliothèque nationale de France]]|location=Paris|pages=125-126}}[http://a.trionfi.eu/WWPCM/decks05/d02108/d02108.htm "Tarot Francais des Fleurs"] at the World Web Playing Card Museum. Retrieved 20 January 2018. It should not be confused with the Italian-suited [[Tarocco Piemontese|Piedmontese tarot]]. ====Bavarian derivatives==== A Parisian variant appeared in Bavaria in the mid-18th century where the king of diamonds wore a [[turban]]. This originates from the [[German playing cards#Southern|German-suited Old Bavarian pattern]]. The king of spades, who used to represent David, no longer holds a harp. This group is closely associated with [[animal tarot]]s. [[File:Атласная колода экстра король черви.jpg|thumb|100px|Russian pattern king of hearts]] The '''Russian pattern''' created during the early 19th-century is based on a Baltic version of a Bavarian derivative.Mann, Sylvia. (1990) All Cards on the Table. Leinfelden: Deutsches Spielkarten-Museum. pp. 277-278.Wintle, Adam. [http://www.wopc.co.uk/russia/ollis Russian Standard Playing Cards] at World of Playing Cards. Retrieved 5 February 2016.[http://www.altacarta.com/english/collect/suits/french/russia.html Russian Pattern] at Alta Carta. Retrieved 5 February 2016. The current appearance was finalized by [[Adolf Charlemagne]]. It usually contains 52 or 36 cards, the latter lacking ranks 2 to 5. The stripped deck is used to play [[Durak]].McLeod, John. [http://www.pagat.com/national/russia.html Card Games in Russia] at [[pagat.com]]. Retrieved 5 February 2016. They can be found in many countries that were once part of the [[Russian Empire]] or [[Soviet Union]]. '''Adler-Cego''' is the last remaining [[animal tarot]] and is used in Germany's [[Black Forest]] to play [[Cego]]. The courts are based off a Frankfurt version of a Bavarian derivative.{{cite book|last1=Mann|first1=Sylvia|title=All Cards on the Table|date=1990|publisher=Deutsches Spielkarten-Museum|location=Leinfelden|pages=83, 315}} It is sold with 54 cards; the 5 to 10 of the red suits and the 1 to 6 of the black suits are removed. Real and fictional animals are displayed on the trump suit but despite its name, eagles do not appear. Trumps have a pink panel in each end with an Arabic numeral to show its rank. The '''[[Industrie und Glück]]''' (Industry and Luck) [[Tarot card games|tarock]] deck of Central Europe uses Roman numerals for the trumps. It is organized in the same manner as the Adler-Cego decks. Its trumps abandoned the traditional allegorical motifs found in Italian tarocchi decks in favor of new, more whimsical scenes like depictions of rural life.[http://i-p-c-s.org/pattern/ps-16.html Austrian Tarock Type C] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 20 February 2016. The turban wearing king is now in the suit of spades. ====Hamburg derivatives==== French-suited cards are popular in Central Europe and compete very well against local [[German playing cards]]. [[Hamburg]] was once a major card-producing hub where makers began revising the Paris pattern. The patterns in this family have the king of spades keeping David's harp. [[Image:Doppelkopfblatt franzoesisches Bild.jpg|thumb|North-German pattern ([[Doppelkopf]] deck)]] The '''North-German pattern''' was created in Stralsund from a Hamburg derivative. It is often erroneously called the Berlin pattern.[http://i-p-c-s.org/pattern/ps-59.html North-German pattern] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 10 September 2016. The crownless queens' hairstyles reflect the [[Biedermeier]] fashions of the day.Wintle, Simon. [http://www.wopc.co.uk/germany/ass/north-german-pattern North German pattern]. Retrieved 5 January 2016. They are usually in decks of 32 cards with the twos to sixes missing since [[skat (card game)|skat]], Germany's most popular card game, does not require a full deck.[http://www.altacarta.com/english/collect/suits/french/berlin.html Berlin pattern] at Alta Carta. Retrieved 5 February 2016. Decks of 36 cards (with the sixes) are for [[jass]] and [[tapp (card game)|tapp]], a game played in [[Baden-Württemberg]]. Decks of 52 cards usually include three jokers but [[Zwickern]] decks have six jokers. The '''French-Swiss pattern''' shares the same descent from the North-German pattern's Hamburg parent but their most distinguishing characteristic is that instead of having corner indices, white Arabic numerals are found within the pips closest to the corner.[http://i-p-c-s.org/pattern/ps-60.html French-Swiss pattern] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 15 February 2016.Pollett, Andrea. [https://web.archive.org/web/20060512043746/http://playingcards.freewebpages.org/cards87.htm Switzerland: French-suited patterns] at Andy's Playing Cards (archived). Retrieved 15 February 2016.[http://www.karten-haus.ch/Schweiz/KartenCHfr.htm Französischschweizer Spielkarten (German)] at kartenhaus. Retrieved 15 February 2016. French-Swiss cards comes only in decks of 36 with no ranks from two to five. The '''Modern Portuguese pattern''' is a Parisian derivative from Germany. When it arrived in Portugal, the kings and jacks in hearts and diamonds swapped suits.[http://i-p-c-s.org/pattern/xp2.html XP2] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 15 February 2016.Gámez, Manuel. [http://www.mydearplayingcards.com/2006_PORTUGAL_HTML/001_Baraja-Fantasia.php Baraja de Fantasia] at My Dear Playing Cards. Retrieved 8 October 2016. The composition consists of 52 cards or until recently 40 cards. The latter had an unusual ranking (ace, king, jack, queen, eight, six–two). The jack ranking higher than the queen comes from the older Portuguese games where a female knave was outranked by the [[Knight (playing card)|knight]].McLeod, John. [http://www.pagat.com/national/portugal.html Card games in Portugal] at [[pagat.com]]. Retrieved 18 February 2016. They also use French-language indices. The '''Dutch pattern''' originates from Germany and shares the same parent as the Modern Portuguese pattern but with different queens. It was not produced in the Netherlands until the 1970s. Their most distinguishing feature are scenic aces.[http://www.i-p-c-s.org/pattern/dutch.html Dutch pattern] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 5 February 2016.[http://www.altacarta.com/english/collect/suits/french/nederland.html The Netherlands Pattern] at Alta Carta. Retrieved 5 February 2016. Also found in [[Flanders]], they come in decks of 32 (no twos to sixes) or 52 cards. The '''[[Trente et Quarante]] pattern''' is named after the game it is associated with.[http://i-p-c-s.org/pattern/ps-65.html Trente et Quarante pattern] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 5 February 2016.[http://www.altacarta.com/english/collect/suits/french/casino.html Casino pattern] at Alta Carta. Retrieved 5 February 2016.Pollett, Andrea. [http://a_pollett.tripod.com/cards41.htm Trente et Quarante cards] at Andy's Playing Cards. Retrieved 5 February 2016. Unlike other patterns, it is usually found only in casinos. Although of German origin, this pattern is now produced only in Italy. They consist of 52 cards and no indices. ====Dondorf Rhineland pattern==== [[File:4kingsPRL.png|thumb|150px|Dondorf Rhineland pattern kings]] Around 1870, Dondorf of Frankfurt produced the Rhineland pattern. The kings have very thick beards. They have fallen out of popularity in Germany but are very common in Poland, Austria, the Netherlands, Denmark, and the [[Baltic states]]. They come in decks of 24 (no 2s to 8s), 32 (no 2s to 6s), or 52 cards, the latter of which may have up to three jokers in some countries.[http://i-p-c-s.org/pattern/donrhine.html Dondorf Rhineland pattern] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 5 February 2016.Wintle, Simon. [http://www.wopc.co.uk/germany/dondorf/rhineland Rhineland pattern] at the World of Playing Cards. Retrieved 5 February 2016. ====Tarot Nouveau==== The [[Tarot Nouveau]] was designed by C.L. Wüst of Frankfurt in the mid-19th century. It is popular in Francophone Europe and Quebec and is also used in Denmark to play tarot games that require the full 78-card deck. Like the [[Industrie und Glück]], the trumps depict genre scenes but modern editions use Arabic numerals instead of Roman ones.[http://i-p-c-s.org/pattern/ps-18.html Bourgeois Tarot] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 17 February 2016. ====Modern Swedish pattern==== Swedes used to use Bavarian derived patterns. In the early 20th-century, the firm Öberg & Son invented a new pattern unrelated to the old ones.Mann, Sylvia. (1990). All Cards on the Table. Leinfelden: Deutsches Spielkarten-Museum. p. 153.Wintle, Simon. [http://www.wopc.co.uk/sweden/standard Standard Swedish Pattern] at World of Playing Cards. Retrieved 5 February 2016.[http://www.altacarta.com/english/collect/suits/french/sverige.html The Swedish Pattern] at Alta Carta. Retrieved 5 February 2016.Pollett, Andrea. [https://web.archive.org/web/20061024073230/http://playingcards.freewebpages.org/cards75.htm Sweden] at Andy's Playing Cards (archived).[http://i-p-c-s.org/pattern/ps-103.html Modern Swedish pattern] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 7 September 2016. This pattern has spread to neighboring Finland. The clothing for the figures in the court cards are color coordinated; green for spades, red for hearts, purple for clubs, and blue for diamonds. They are in the standard 52-card format. ===English pattern=== [[Image:King of Hearts Ruen pattern comparison.jpg|right|350px|thumb|Evolution of the king of hearts from the Rouennais to English pattern]] Card makers from [[Rouen]] began exporting to England around 1480.[http://i-p-c-s.org/pattern/ps-48.html English pattern] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 5 February 2016. Since Latin-suited cards were already circulating in England, the English renamed French suits to the Latin ones with which they were familiar. Hence the clovers were called clubs and pikes were named after the swords (''spade''). The English did not start producing their own cards until a century later. In 1628, the importation of foreign playing cards was banned to protect local manufacturers. English cardmakers produced lower quality cards than their continental counterparts leading to the loss of detail from the Rouennais pattern. Today's pattern is the result of Charles Goodall and Son's reworking of the old Rouen pattern during the 19th century.Wintle, Adam. [http://www.wopc.co.uk/goodall/index Charles Goodall and Son] at the World of Playing Cards. Retrieved 5 February 2016. The majority of decks sold in this pattern is the [[Standard 52-card deck|52 card deck]]. One deck invented in the United States but more commonly found in Australia and New Zealand contains 11s, 12s, and red 13s to play the six-handed version of the [[Euchre]] variant [[500 (card game)|500]].McLeod, John. [https://www.pagat.com/euchre/500.html Five Hundred] at [[Pagat.com]]. Retrieved 31 January 2017. In the late nineteenth century, they were also used for variants of [[draw poker]] and [[Cassino (card game)#Royal Cassino|royal cassino]].{{cite journal|last1=Burton|first1=Jeffrey|title=French Suited 60-Card Decks|journal=[[The Playing-Card]]|date=1999|volume=28|issue=2|pages=63-64}}{{cite journal|last1=Pratesi|first1=Franco|title=Casino from nowhere, to vaguely everywhere|journal=[[The Playing-Card]]|date=1995|volume=24|issue=1|page=10}} Decks marketed for [[Canasta]] often have card point values printed on the cards. ===Vienna pattern=== [[Image:Francia kártya - Piatnik Nándor és Fiai Rt. (12).tif|right|thumb|100px|Vienna pattern king of hearts]] [[Lyon]] was a major card exporter to German speaking countries from the late 16th through the 18th centuries.[http://i-p-c-s.org/pattern/ps-62.html portrait d'Allemagne] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 5 February 2016.Wintle, Simon. [http://www.wopc.co.uk/france/lyons-pattern-3 Lyons pattern type iii] at the World of Playing Cards. Retrieved 27 September 2016. While the Lyonnais pattern died out in most places, it survived in Austria and the Czech Republic and its modern incarnations is the Vienna pattern.Wintle, Simon. [http://www.wopc.co.uk/austria/wiener Wiener pattern] at the World of Playing Cards. Retrieved 5 February 2016.[http://www.altacarta.com/english/collect/suits/french/wien.html Vienna pattern] at Alta Carta. Retrieved 5 February 2016.[http://i-p-c-s.org/pattern/ps-107.html Vienna pattern, large crown] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 7 September 2016. They come in decks of 24 (no 2s to 8s), 32 (no 2s to 6s), or 52 cards, the latter with corner indices and three jokers. ===Lombard pattern=== The Lombard or Milanese pattern come in 40 card decks that is missing the 8s, 9s, and 10s and lack corner indices. The Lombard decks exported to [[Swiss Italian]] regions contain corner indices and also labels the ranks of the face cards.[http://www.altacarta.com/english/collect/suits/french/lombarde.html Lombard pattern] at Alta Carta. Retrieved 5 February 2016. It is probably derived from the Lyonnais pattern and its offshoot, the extinct Provence pattern.Wintle, Simon. [http://www.wopc.co.uk/italy/lombard Lombardy Type] at World of Playing Cards. Retrieved 5 February 2016.Mann, Sylvia. (1990) All Cards on the Table. Leinfelden: Deutsches Spielkarten-Museum. pp.43-44. ===Tuscan pattern=== The Tuscan or Florentine pattern, dating from the mid-19th century, is the only French suited deck that is not reversible in the present.Wintle, Adam. [http://www.wopc.co.uk/italy/florentine Florentine type] at the World of Playing Cards. Retrieved 18 February 2016.[http://www.altacarta.com/english/collect/suits/french/toscane.html Tuscan pattern] at Alta Carta. Retrieved 5 February 2016. Cards measure 58 × 88 mm but the ''Toscane Grandi'' by [[Modiano (company)|Modiano]] are 67 × 101 mm large. It has the same composition of cards as the Lombard pattern. There was another pattern called "Tuscan" but it has ceased printing since the 1980s.{{cite book|last1=Mann|first1=Sylvia|title=All Cards on the Table|date=1990|publisher=Deutsches Spielkarten-Museum|location=Leinfelden|pages=44-45, 301-303|ref=Florentine}}[http://www.altacarta.com/overview/toscane.html Old Tuscany Pattern] at Alta Carta. Retrieved 25 September 2016. {{clear}} ===Baronesse pattern=== [[File:Skatkarten - Könige.jpg|thumb|120px|Baronesse pattern kings]] Dondorf of Frankfurt produced this pattern around 1900 and now it is used in [[Patience (game)|Patience]] decks by many companies worldwide. The court cards are dressed in [[rococo]] period costumes.Mann, Sylvia. (1990). All Cards on the Table. Leinfelden: Deutsches Spielkarten-Museum. p.77, 300.Wintle, Simon. [http://www.wopc.co.uk/germany/dondorf/baronesse Baronesse Whist No.160] at the World of Playing Cards. Retrieved 20 February 2016. ==See also== * [[Standard 52-card deck]] * [[Playing cards in Unicode]] {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Playing cards}} {{Playing card decks}} [[Category:French card games]] [[Category:Playing card decks]] [[Category:Game equipment]]

{{Infobox video game |title = |image = Hugo BDF PSX.png |image_size = 256px |caption = Cover art of the PlayStation version |developer = [[ITE Media]]
([[Kiloo|Kiloo ApS]]) |publisher = [[Electronic Arts]]
([[Kiloo|Kiloo ApS]]) |producer = Lars Rikart Jensen
Jacob Buck
Philip Mundt |designer = Kim Krogh
Johnny Haarup
Elsa Søby |programmer = Jesper Olsen
Christian Cordes
Nicolai Mouritzen |artist = Johnny Haarup
Claus Friese
Peter E. Paulsen |composer = David Filskov
Christian S. Jensen
Asbjørn Andersen |series = ''[[Hugo (series)|Hugo]]'' |released = 2001-2004 |genre = [[Platform game]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[PlayStation]], [[Game Boy Color]], [[Mobile game|Mobile]] }} '''''Hugo: Black Diamond Fever''''' is a 3D platform game in the ''[[Hugo (franchise)|Hugo]]'' series that was developed by [[ITE Media]] and published by [[Electronic Arts]] in 2001 for the PC and [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]]. In 2003, a 2D [[Game Boy Color]] version was also created. In 2004, it was ported by Kiloo ApS for mobile phones. ==Gameplay== [[File:Hugo_BDF_gameplay.jpg|thumb|left|Gameplay on the PlayStation]] {{expand section|date=April 2013}} The 3D version of the game adaptation resembles ''[[Croc: Legend of the Gobbos]]'' or ''[[Crash Bandicoot (video game)|Crash Bandicoot]]''. The 2D version is more reminiscent of ''[[Bomb Jack]]''. ==Plot== ''The evil Scylla is back and this time has found a way to make herself the most powerful witch of all time and take over the world. For this, she requires very rare black diamonds, which are to be found on the jungle island where the Kikurians live. She takes them all prisoner and forces them to work day and night in search of black diamonds. The elder King Kikurian asks Hugo the troll to liberate the slaves and stop Scylla's plot before it is too late. When Fernando arrives a letter from King Kikurian, Hugo reads it, but finds poor King Kikurian imprisoned in a cell and unable to help his people, and has absolutely no time to waste. Can Hugo free all the slaves and stop Scylla's plot?'' ==Reception== {{Video game reviews |GSpot = 7.1/10 (Mobile){{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/hugo-black-diamond-fever/reviews/hugo-black-diamond-fever-review-6102758/ |title=Hugo - Black Diamond Fever Review |publisher=GameSpot.com |date=2004-12-31 |accessdate=2013-12-22}} |GameZone = 2.8/10 (PS1){{cite web|url=http://www.ite.dk/reviews/bdf_www.gamezone.de.pdf |title=Hugo - Diamantenfieber |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-12-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030422012945/http://www.ite.dk/reviews/bdf_www.gamezone.de.pdf |archivedate=April 22, 2003 }} |rev1=[[MSN]] |rev1Score= {{Rating|4|6}} (PS1){{cite web|url=http://www.ite.dk/reviews/bdf_www.gamezone.de.pdf |title=Hvor skal vi hen, du? (Playstation) |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-12-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030422012945/http://www.ite.dk/reviews/bdf_www.gamezone.de.pdf |archivedate=April 22, 2003 }} |rev2=[[Wirtualna Polska]] |rev2Score= {{Rating|3|5}} (PC){{cite web|author=Anna Wojewódzka |url=http://gry.wp.pl/recenzja/hugo-goraczka-czarnych-diamentow,1899,1.html |title=Hugo: Gorączka Czarnych Diamentów - Recenzja - Imperium gier - WP.PL |publisher=Gry.wp.pl |date=2007-05-24 |accessdate=2013-12-22}} }}{{expand section|date=April 2013}} Danish gaming website GameSector awarded it the scores of 7/10 for the PC version,{{cite web|author=Gamesector.dk |url=http://www.gamesector.dk/2001/11/10/hugo-black-diamond-fever/ |title=Hugo Black Diamond Fever (PC) |date= |accessdate=2013-12-22}} and 8/10 for the PlayStation,{{cite web|author=Gamesector.dk |url=http://www.gamesector.dk/2001/11/15/hugo-black-diamond-fever/ |title=Hugo Black Diamond Fever (GBC) |date= |accessdate=2013-12-22}} and 8/10 for the Game Boy Color.{{cite web|author=Gamesector.dk |url=http://www.gamesector.dk/2001/11/16/hugo-black-diamond-fever/ |title=Hugo Black Diamond Fever (PS) |date= |accessdate=2013-12-22}} ==See also== *''[[Hugo: Quest for the Sunstones]]'', a prequel to the game. *[[Hugo (series)|Other ''Hugo'' video games]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.mobygames.com/game/hugo-black-diamond-fever ''Hugo: Black Diamond Fever'' (Mobile)] at [[MobyGames]] {{Hugo franchise}} [[Category:2001 video games]] [[Category:Game Boy Color games]] [[Category:Hugo video games]] [[Category:Mobile games]] [[Category:PlayStation (console) games]] [[Category:Platform games]] [[Category:Single-player video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Denmark]] [[Category:Video games featuring female antagonists]] [[Category:Windows games]]

revision.text:
The '''Katherine Dunham Company''', a troupe of dancers, singers, actors and musicians, was the first African-American [[modern dance]] company. It descended from '''Ballet Nègre''', a student troupe founded in 1930 by [[Katherine Dunham]], which later became the '''Negro Dance Group'''.
The company had successful runs on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] and in other major American cities. In a ''[[The New York Times]]'' review on February 19, 1940, dance critic [[John Martin (dance critic)|John Martin]] wrote: "Her performance with her group last Sunday at the Windsor Theatre may very well become a historic occasion, for certainly never before in all efforts of recent years to establish Negro dance as a serious medium has there been so convincing and authoritative an approach."<ref>John Martin, "The Dance: A Negro Art", ''New York Times'', February 19, 1940. Quoted in [http://brbl-archive.library.yale.edu/exhibitions/awia/chicago.pdf "City of Lake and Wind"], ''Chicago Renaissance'', p. 19. Yale University.</ref><ref>Molly E. Christie Gonzalez, [http://digitalcommons.brockport.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1003&context=dns_theses "Katherine Dunham Technique and Philosophy: A Holistic Dance Pedagogy"] (2015). Dance Master’s Theses. Paper 4.</ref> Beginning in the 1940s Dunham took her troupe on a series of highly acclaimed world tours. The Dunham Company helped launch the career of many [[African-American]] performers of the day. Dunham alumni include [[Alvin Ailey]], [[Rosalie King]], [[Eartha Kitt]] and [[Walter Nicks]]. Today you can find classes in Dunham Technique taught in [[New York City]] at both the [[92nd Street Y|92nd Street YMHA]] and at the [[Fashion Institute of Technology]], by former company member Dana McBroom-Manno. McBroom-Manno was a featured dancer in the [[Metropolitan Opera]]'s production of ''[[Aida]]'', choreographed by Katherine Dunham, the first African-American choreographer at the Met since [[Hemsley Winfield]] set the dances for ''[[The Emperor Jones]]'' in 1933.
Successful revues included the universally acclaimed ''[[Bal Nègre]]'' (1946).
==See also== * [[Modern dance]] * [[Postmodern dance]] * [[20th-century concert dance]] * [[List of dance companies]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://fora.tv/2002/06/26/Katherine_Dunham_on_Overcoming_1940s_Racism "Katherine Dunham on Overcoming 1940s Racism"]. Katherine Dunham speaking at a June 6, 2002, Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival PillowTalk. * [http://lcweb2.loc.gov/cocoon/ihas/html/dunham/dunham-timeline.html Katherine Dunham timeline] - includes information about the development of her company. * [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0242281/ Katherine Dunham IMDb entry] - includes a list of films in which she appeared, choreographed and/or her Company appeared.
[[Category:African-American dance]] [[Category:Dance companies in the United States]]
{{Dance-stub}}

{{Lede too short|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Leyou | logo = | type = [[Public company|Public]] | industry = Video games | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = <!-- if known: {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} in [[city]], [[state]], [[country]] --> | founder = Alex Xu | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location_city = | hq_location_country = [[Hong Kong]] | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = Video games | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = | website = {{URL|leyoutech.com.hk/}} }}
'''Leyou''' is a global video game holding company focused on [[free-to-play]] console and [[PC game|PC gaming]]. Leyou, which had originally operated as a chicken supplier, now has three holdings, [[Digital Extremes]], [[Splash Damage]] (both developers) and Athlon Games (publisher).
== Overview == In 2015, Leyou became part-owner of Canadian developer [[Digital Extremes]] the developer and publisher of ''[[Warframe]]'' game on consoles and PC. Leyou purchased Digital Extremes in 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://venturebeat.com/2017/09/02/gamesbeat-boss-interview-chinas-leyou-moves-from-chicken-meat-to-triple-a-game-publishing/|title=GamesBeat Boss interview: China’s Leyou moves from chicken meat to triple-A game publishing|date=2017-09-02|work=VentureBeat|access-date=2018-07-23|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.lexpert.ca/article/leyou-technologies-acquires-39-of-digital-extremes-for-us65-million/?p=14%7C119|title=Lexpert ® {{!}} Leyou Technologies acquires 39% of Digital Extremes for US$65 million|access-date=2018-07-23|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://games.mxdwn.com/news/leyou-technologies-holdings-purchases-digital-extremes-creators-of-warframe/|title=Leyou Technologies Holdings Purchases Digital Extremes, Creators of Warframe -|date=2016-01-06|work=mxdwn Games|access-date=2018-07-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
In July 2016, the sale of British games developer [[Splash Damage]] to [[Radius Maxima]] (a Leyou subsidiary)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2016-07-11-splash-damage-sold-to-chinese-poultry-firm|title=Splash Damage sold to Chinese poultry firm|author=|date=|website=gamesindustry.biz|accessdate=22 March 2018}}</ref> was announced, for up to $150 million by [[Paul Wedgwood]], its sole owner, co-founder and chief executive.<ref name="theguardian1">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/jul/12/chinese-chicken-supplier-leyou-buys-uk-games-developer-splash-damage|title=Chinese chicken supplier buys UK games developer Splash Damage | Technology|author=Alex Hern|date=|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=2016-07-16}}</ref> <ref name="eurogamer1">{{cite web|last=Purchese |first=Robert |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-07-11-splash-damage-acquired-by-chinese-chicken-meat-company-leyou |title=Splash Damage bought by Chinese chicken meat company Leyou • |website=Eurogamer.net |date=2016-07-11 |accessdate=2016-07-16}}</ref>
In 2017, Leyou invested $10 million in Austin-based game developer, [[Certain Affinity]] to develop original games.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.siliconhillsnews.com/2017/10/17/austin-game-maker-certain-affinity-lands-10-million-investment-hong-kong-firm/|title=Austin Game Maker Certain Affinity Lands $10 Million Investment from Hong Kong Firm - SiliconHills|date=2017-10-17|work=SiliconHills|access-date=2018-07-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
In May 2018, Leyou launched a video game publishing label known as [[Athlon Games]] based in [[California]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2018-05-23-digital-extremes-chinese-owner-stealthily-launches-new-us-publisher|title=Digital Extremes' Chinese owner stealthily launches new US publisher|last=|first=|date=|website=GamesIndustry.biz|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=24 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.resetera.com/threads/leyou-tech-established-game-publishing-division-in-usa-spearheaded-by-former-wbie-vp-director.29846/|title=Leyou Tech Established Game Publishing Division in USA Spearheaded by Former WBIE VP & Director|publisher=|accessdate=24 May 2018}}</ref>
In September 2018, Leyou announced a partnership between Athlon Games and [[Middle-earth Enterprises]] to publish a multi-year online free to play game based on [[The Lord of the Rings]] fantasy work of [[J.R.R. Tolkien]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://leyoutech.com.hk/athlon-games-inc|title=Athlon Games Partners with Middle-earth Enterprises|website=leyoutech.com.hk|date=2018-09-03||accessdate=17 September 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Video game companies of China]] [[Category:Video game development companies]]

[[File:Flag of Kyrgyzstan.svg|thumb|right|200px]] The Kyrgyz film industry produced over five feature films in [[2014 in film|2014]]. This article fully lists all non-pornographic films, including short films, that had a release date in that year and which were at least partly made by [[Kyrgyzstan]]. It does not include films first released in previous years that had release dates in 2014.
Also included is an overview of the major events in Kyrgyz film, including film festivals and awards ceremonies, as well as lists of those films that have been particularly well received, both critically and financially. ==Major releases== {| class="wikitable" |+ "align=bottom" | |- style="background:#b0e0e6; text-align:center;" ! colspan="2" | Opening ! style="width:24%;"| Title ! style="width:40%;"| Cast and Crew ! [[File:NDK Sofia 2012 PD 06.jpg|thumb|300px|Night view of NDK]]
'''The [[National Palace of Culture]]''' (short NDK) is one of the major venues in [[Sofia]], [[Bulgaria]]. The main Hall 1 with its more than 3500 comfortable seats has hosted many famous performers and hit spectacles.<ref name="NDK history">{{cite web|url=http://www.ndk.bg/istoriq|title=Начало - NDK|website=www.ndk.bg|accessdate=24 February 2018}}</ref>
Below is a list of some of the events that have been held there.

Agro TV
Profit.ro | timeshift names = | web = [http://looktv.ro/ looktv.ro] | terr serv 1 = | terr chan 1 = | terr serv 2 = | terr chan 2 = | sat serv 1 = | sat chan 1 = | sat serv 2 = | sat chan 2 = | sat serv 3 = | sat chan 3 = | sat serv 4 = | sat chan 4 = | sat serv 5 = | sat chan 5 = | cable serv 1 = | cable chan 1 = | cable serv 2 = | cable chan 2 = | adsl serv 1 = | adsl chan 1 = }} '''LookPlus''' (formerly '''Transilvania L!VE''') is a television channel from [[Romania]], launched on December 19, 2011.[http://bistritaonline.ro/2011/11/23/paszkany-rus-si-dancu-vor-lansa-in-decembrie-postul-transilvania-live-care-va-emite-si-national/ Paszkany, Rus şi Dâncu vor lansa, în decembrie, postul Transilvania Live, care va emite şi naţional][http://www.napocanews.ro/2012/02/lansare-transilvania-live-tv-in-rosu-alb-si-verde-400-de-clujeni-au-infruntat-gerul-sa-participe-la-concertul-din-piata-unirii-fotovideo.html Lansare Transilvania Live TV în roşu, alb şi verde. 400 de clujeni au înfruntat gerul să participe la concertul din Piaţa Unirii (Foto+Video)] It was run by Transilvania Media Group, a media company owned by businessman Arpad Paszkany, which also owned [[LookSport]]. The two stations were sold to [[Intel Sky Broadcasting LTD]] in March 2014, and then to Clever Media Network SRL in September 2017, owned by businessman Adrian Tomşa. ==High-definition== [[File:Logo LookPlus HD (2018).svg|100px|left]] LookPlus is available in [[High-definition television|high-definition]] as a separate channel, accordingly named '''LookPlus HD'''. ==Shows== * Bucătăria lui Teo, is a [[Romania]]n [[television]] cooking show, host Teo * Jurnal de Psiholog, host Raluca Anton * Seară bună, hosts Cristina Szekely and Marius Aciu * Tonik Show, is a [[Romania]]n [[television]] [[comedy]] show, host Nicu Bendea * Vine Vaida pe la Voi, is a [[Romania]]n [[television]] traditional music show, host Sergiu Vitalian Vaida ==Sport competions== * {{flagicon|ROU}} [[Liga I]] * {{flagicon|ROU}} [[Liga II]] * {{flagicon|BEL}} [[Belgian First Division A]] * {{flagicon|SCO}} [[Scottish Premiership]] * {{flagicon|ROU}} [[Divizia A1 (men's volleyball)|Divizia A1 M]] * {{flagicon|ROU}} [[Divizia A1 (women's volleyball)|Divizia A1 W]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://looktv.ro/ Official website] {{Television in Romania}} {{DEFAULTSORT:LookPlus}} [[Category:Television stations in Romania]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2012]] {{tv-stub}}

page.title: Macalester Plymouth United Church Hymn Contest

revision.text:
The '''Macalester Plymouth United Church Hymn Contest''' is a highly regarded annual search for new [[hymns]] instituted by a leading [[Minnesota]] congregation which is a union of the [[United Church of Christ]] (UCC) and the [[Presbyterian Church (USA)]].<ref>''Contest At Minn. Church Brings New Hymns'', The Associated Press; Mar. 5, 2008</ref>
==History== Since 1996, Macalester Plymouth United Church of [[St. Paul, Minnesota]], has sponsored a hymn-writing contest seeking new hymn texts that "can motivate the church to be more actively involved in social reform." The St. Paul contest is funded with an endowment by A.A. "Al" Heckman, a church member who was widely known as Minnesota’s “Dean of [[Philanthropy]]” who died in 1994.
The longest-running [[English language]] hymn contest attracts entries from the [[United States]] and the rest of the English-speaking world, including [[Great Britain]], [[Canada]], and [[Australia]]. In church hymn circles, the hymn contest has acquired a level of importance capable of elevating a previously unknown artist to international prominence and providing deserved recognition of established hymn writers.<ref>See: http://www.macalester-plymouth.org/</ref>
==Annual Themes and Winning Hymns== Chronological list includes co-winning hymns and honorable mention hymns.<ref>For more information see: ''[http://www.macalester-plymouth.org/documents/MPUCHymnContestHistory.pdf An Historical Overview of the Macalester Plymouth United Church Hymn Contest] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727051834/http://www.macalester-plymouth.org/documents/MPUCHymnContestHistory.pdf |date=2011-07-27 }}''</ref>
'''1996 Theme: Hymns that call the church to work for social justice''' * 1996 Winning hymn ''Who Will Speak a Word of Warning'' - [[Richard Leach]],<ref>see: http://www.selahpub.com/SelahPeople/Leach.html</ref> Torrington, CT
'''1997 Theme: Hymns that call the church to nurture and care for children everywhere''' * 1997 Winning hymn ''Gentle Jesus, Loving Shepherd'' - Lurline DuPre, Denton, TX * 1997 Honorable mention ''The Children We Hold Dear'' - David A. Robb, Dalton, GA<ref>see: http://www.selahpub.com/SelahPeople/Robb.html</ref> * 1997 Honorable mention ''The People Came from Everywhere'' - Mary Nelson Keithahn, Belle Fourche, SD<ref>see: http://www.hymnsetc.com/keithahn.html</ref>
'''1998 Theme: Hymns that speak to the role and ministry of the church in addressing social concerns faced by our communities, our nation and our world as we enter a new century''' * 1998 Winning hymn ''How Long Ago the World Was Taught'' - [[Richard Leach]], Torrington, CT<ref>''Connecticut Pastor Wins Hymn-writing Contest''; Star Tribune (Minneapolis, MN), March 13, 1999</ref> * 1998 Honorable mention ''Companion of the Poor'' - Dan Damon, Point Richmond, CA<ref>see: http://www.damonstuneshop.com/aboutdan.htm{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 1998 Honorable mention ''God Has Asked “Whom Shall I Send Forth?”'' - Michael Morgan, Atlanta, GA * 1998 Honorable mention ''O Hear My Voice, My People'' - Robert Gardiner, Southampton, MA
'''1999 Theme: Hymns which address [[Natural environment|environmental]] [[stewardship]] at a time of conflicting national / tribal interests''' * 1999 Winning hymn ''The Garden Needs Our Tending Now'' - Mary Louise Bringle, Laurinberg, NC<ref>see: http://www.giamusic.com/bios/mary-louise-bringle</ref>
'''2000 Theme: Hymns based on the [[Nevi'im|Hebrew prophets]]’ calls for [[justice]]''' * 2000 Winning hymn ''As the Bear That Roams the Timber'' - John Core, Morgantown, WV<ref>see: http://www.reformedworship.org/about/bio.cfm?person_id=105{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
'''2001 Theme: Hymns which call the church to greater [[Inclusion (value and practice)|inclusivity]]''' * 2001 Winning hymn ''O God, By Whose Guidance'' - Robert Gardiner, Southampton, MA
'''2002 Theme: Hymns which call the church to affirm [[gay]], [[lesbian]], [[bisexual]] and [[transgender]] persons and to celebrate their gifts and ministries'''<ref>Shower of Stoles Project website: http://www.welcomingresources.org/sospWorshipRes.htm</ref> * 2002 Co-winning hymn ''Faces and Facets'' - Alan J. Hommerding, Chicago, IL<ref>see: {{cite web|url=http://www.wlp.jspaluch.com/338.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713123133/http://www.wlp.jspaluch.com/338.htm |archivedate=2011-07-13 |df= }}</ref> * 2002 Co-winning hymn ''In the Desert Where They’d Wandered'' - Richard Spalding, Williamstown, MA<ref>see: http://www.williams.edu/chaplain/staff.php</ref> * 2002 Co-winning hymn ''The Love That Goes Unspoken'' - Mary Louise Bringle, Etowah, NC
'''2003 Theme: Hymns which call the church and its people to work for [[peace]]''' * 2003 Winning hymn ''O God of Peace, Who Gave Us Breath and Birth'' - [[Timothy Dudley-Smith]], Salisbury, UK * 2003 Honorable mention ''God Is Still Speaking'' - Barbara Hamm, Martinez, CA
'''2004 Theme: Hymns which celebrate religious diversity and encourage [[interfaith]] [[cooperation]], with the understanding that many of the world’s social problems are rooted in [[religious intolerance]]''' * 2004 Winning hymn ''Creator of the Intertwined'' - Jacque B. Jones, Brooklyn, NY<ref>see: http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_7559/is_200807/ai_n32306989/pg_2/</ref>
'''2005 Theme: Hymns which call the church and its people to greater awareness of the plight of the [[homeless]], and to the need for [[affordable housing]] for all people''' * 2005 Winning hymn ''The Church of Christ Cannot be Bound'' - Adam M. L. Tice, Goshen, IN<ref>see: http://www.adammltice.com/</ref> * 2005 Honorable mention ''If God Is Anywhere At All'' - Pamela Payne, Huntsville, AL * 2005 Honorable mention ''A Home for All Is God’s Desire'' - William Allen Pasch, Griffin, GA<ref>see http://www.augsburgfortress.org/store/itemcontributor.jsp?contributorcode=5565{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
'''2006 Theme: Hymns that call the church and its people to practice the [[forgiveness]] of enemies and to commend to the nations as practical politics the search for cooperation and peace.''' * 2006 Co-winning hymn ''Disarming Presence, Win Us'' - Dorothy Fulton, Abington, Pennsylvania * 2006 Co-winning hymn ''To Dream of It Is Wondrous'' - John Core, Morgantown, West Virginia
'''2007: Theme: New hymns to use on [[Mother's Day]], sensitive to the changing nature of family life, and affirming feminist calls for equality.'''<ref>Presbyterian Association of Musicians May 2007 newsletter</ref> * 2007 Winning hymn: ''Thank You, God, For Mother'' - Nathan Crabtree, Hickory, NC<ref>see: {{cite web|url=http://www.macalester-plymouth.org/documents/Quest_For_Hymns_About_Social_Justice_MacalesterPlymouthUnitedChurch.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727051329/http://www.macalester-plymouth.org/documents/Quest_For_Hymns_About_Social_Justice_MacalesterPlymouthUnitedChurch.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-27 |df= }}</ref> * 2007 Honorable mention ''O Loving Creator, We Labor with You'' - [[Jann Aldredge-Clanton]], Dallas, TX<ref>see: http://www.jannaldredgeclanton.com/music.php</ref>
'''2008: Theme: Hymns which will enable the church and its people to lament, to cry out in anger and frustration to God.''' * 2008 Co-winning hymn ''When Brutal Forces Crush Out Love'' - R. Frederick Crider, Jr., Timonium, MD * 2008 Co-winning hymn ''Earth Is Aching'' - David Gambrell, Louisville, KY<ref>see: http://www.pres-outlook.com/reports-a-resources/lent/9619-lenten-hymns.html</ref> * 2008 Co-winning hymn ''Can We Curse Without Blaspheming?'' - William Allen Pasch, Griffin, GA
'''2009: Theme: Hymns to be sung on [[Labor Day]], with words that especially address the plight of the unemployed.''' * 2009 Winning hymn ''God Bless the Work Your People Do'' - [[John A. Dalles]], Longwood, FL * 2009 Honorable mention ''When Work of Heart and Hand Align'' - Pamela Payne, Huntsville, AL
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Macalester Plymouth United Church Hymn Contest}} [[Category:Hymnology]] [[Category:Competitions]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1996]]

revision.text:
'''Michael Aloysius "Mike" Connors''' (1891 - 1949) was an Australian [[vaudevillian]] and [[radio presenter]].
He was born in [[New York City|New York]] and came to Australia in 1916 on a six-month stage contract as part of a vaudeville act, contracted by [[Ben Fuller (producer)|Benjamin Fuller]].<ref>(17 January 1949) [https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/216544840 'Mike' - hero to sick], ''The Telegraph''. Retrieved 24 October 2018.</ref>
After arriving in Australia, Connors met [[Queenie Paul]] whom he co-starred with in a revue.<ref name=queenie>Lees, Jennie [http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/paul-eveline-pauline-queenie-15034 Paul, Eveline Pauline (Queenie) (1893 - 1982)], ''[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]'', Volume 18, 2012. Accessed 24 October 2018.</ref>
Connors and Paul married in [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]] on 17 November 1917, and the couple subsequently became known for their collaborative stage work.<ref name=queenie/><ref>(15 December 1922) [https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/83262079 Vaudevillians Arrive - Connors and Paul for the Royal], ''[[The Daily News (Perth)|The Daily News]]''. Retrieved 24 October 2018.</ref><ref>(24 February 1930) [https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/16628217 Last curtain on vaudeville at Fuller's - theatre going Over to talkies], ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]''. Retrieved 24 October 2018.</ref><ref>(27 December 1933) [https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/186135976 Connors and Paul back with 'flying colours'], ''[[The Daily Standard (Brisbane)|The Daily Standard]]''. Retrieved 24 October 2018.</ref>
After gaining financial backing in 1931, Connors and Paul established Con-Paul Theatres.<ref name=queenie/> In 1932, Con-Paul Theatres took over the lease of the Grand Opera House in Sydney and renamed it the [[New Tivoli Theatre, Sydney|New Tivoli Theatre]].<ref>McPherson, Ailsa (2010) [https://dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/new_tivoli_theatre Entry: New Tivoli Theatre], Dictionary of Sydney. Retrieved 24 October 2018.</ref>
The couple had three children together, Celestine, Colleen and Paul. Colleen Connors died at the age of five in December 1933 from [[meningitis]].<ref>(20 January 1934) [https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/235495009 Human tragedy too deep for tears - vaudevillians mask their sorrow with smiles], ''[[Smith's Weekly]]''. Retrieved 24 October 2018.</ref>
In 1938, Connors began working in radio at the [[Australian Broadcasting Commission|ABC]], hosting a national breakfast program and ''The Hospital Half-Hour''.<ref name=axed>(3 May 1975) [https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/110636145 Hospital Hour to end], ''[[The Canberra Times]]''. Retrieved 24 October 2018.</ref> Connors became seriously ill in 1948 from what was reported to be a [[blood clot]]. During his illness, he received many messages of support including one from Australian Prime Minister [[Ben Chifley]]. <ref>(12 December 1948) [https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/169381259 Mike's a lot thinner now], ''[[Truth (Melbourne newspaper)|Truth]]''. Retrieved 24 October 2018.</ref> He returned to radio in December 1948, only to again fall ill several weeks later with his condition worsening.<ref>(17 January 1949) [https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/18103438 Personality on radio - Death of 'Mike' Connors], ''The Sydney Morning Herald''. Retrieved 24 October 2018.</ref>
Mike Connors died at the age of 57 on 16 January 1949.<ref>(17 January 1949) [https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/49910089 Comedian's last bow], ''[[The Courier-Mail]]''. Retrieved 24 October 2018.</ref> Fellow entertainers [[Roy Rene]], [[Jack Davey]], [[Harry Pringle (producer)|Harry Pringle]], [[George Wallace (Australian comedian)|George Wallace]], Jim Gussey and Reg Quartley served as [[pallbearers]] at Connors' funeral.<ref>(19 January 1949) [https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/117088506 Mike Connors' funeral], ''[[Queensland Times]]''. Retrieved 24 October 2018.</ref> Radio announcer [[Russ Tyson]], who was already filling in for Connors during his ill health, replaced Connors on his radio programs.<ref>Burns, Nelson (16 January 1949) [https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/98284734 Carrying On For Mike], ''[[The Sunday Mail (Brisbane)|The Sunday Mail]]''. Retrieved 24 October 2018.</ref><ref name=axed/>
Connors' widow, Queenie Paul commenced working nine months after the death of her husband.<ref>(9 October 1949) [https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/229224794 Comedian's widow stages comeback], ''[[The Sun (Sydney)|The Sun]]''. Retrieved 24 October 2018.</ref>
== References == <!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. --> {{reflist}}
{{Theat-stub}} {{Australia-radio-bio-stub}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Connors, Mike}} [[Category:1891 births]] [[Category:1949 deaths]] [[Category:Australian radio presenters]] [[Category:American emigrants to Australia]] [[Category:Vaudeville performers]]

{{multiple issues| {{COI|date=March 2016}} {{notability|Organizations|date=March 2016}} {{unreferenced|date=March 2016}} }} {{Infobox organization |name = Miss Teen Thailand |image = Miss Teen Thailand logo.jpg |image_border = |size = 250px |caption = Logo of Miss Teen Thailand pageant. |map = |msize = |mcaption = |motto = |formation = {{start date and years ago|1989}} |type = [[Beauty Pageant]] |headquarters = [[Bangkok]] |location = [[Thailand]] |membership = |language = [[Thai language|Thai]] |leader_title = Company |leader_name = Inspire Entertainment Co.,Ltd. |key_people = |num_staff = |budget = |website = [http://www.missteenthailand.com Official Website] }} '''Miss Teen Thailand''' is a beauty contest for Thai girls aged 15–18. The pageant is organised and sponsored by Inspire Entertainment Co., Ltd.
The reigning Miss Teen Thailand is Varisara Sripetch, who was crowned on October 26, 2015 in Bangkok by Pattanida Poomchusang, Miss Teen Thailand 2014.
==History==
Miss Teen Thailand, a national pageant for teenage girls was first held in 1989. The pageant was created by the [[Miss Thailand]] organisation, in co-operation with Channel 7 television studios. Miss Teen Thailand was transferred from the Yod Phu Thai company to Inspire Entertainment Co., Ltd. in 2002.
The entry requirements for Miss Teen Thailand is that girls must be of the ages between 15 - 17, which was later adjusted to 18 in 1998.
Prizes are awarded to the top 5 contestants, that being 3 (second runner), 1 (first runner) and the winner. A cash prize, gifts and endorsements deals are awarded to the contestants and a contract with Inspire Entertainment and Channel 7 for 7 years is awarded to the winner. Many previous winners and runners-up have gone on to achieve success in the entertainment industry, ranging from modelling, acting, singing and presenting.
Miss Teen Thailand is regarded as one of the four major beauty contest in Thailand.
